.vscode/launch.json

{
  // Use IntelliSense to learn about possible attributes.
  // Hover to view descriptions of existing attributes.
  // For more information, visit: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=830387
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "type": "pwa-chrome",
      "request": "launch",
      "name": "Launch Chrome against localhost",
      "url": "http://localhost:3000",
      "webRoot": "${workspaceFolder}"
    }
  ]
}

README.md

## Introduction

Please see [The EvictorBook Developer's Guide](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1NnJ_Yd_Av8S2bFs5MceeA73BXmx0Ebvy_hJ4xNJI1IA/edit#heading=h.7gbjrtcbk8kv) for an in-depth introduction to the project.

See also [EvictorBook Community Agreements](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1kUGeOOMEB-_N5oLhi8TK01EW33pmATzyXW8O7-gldw4/edit)

## EvictorBook Setup

This guide summarizes the steps needed to build and run `EvictorBook` from source code, with steps for troubleshooting common problems.

    BEFORE YOU START: please be aware that building the production branch immediately followed by the staging branch can cause problems with your dev environment.

### Dev Environment

1. Download or clone the repository: `https://github.com/antievictionmappingproject/evictorbook.git`

1. Switch to the `STAGING` branch (IMPORTANT)
   <br/><br/>
   The `STAGING` branch is the `correct branch` to work from for anyone new to the project
   Building the production branch immediately followed by the staging branch `can cause problems` with your dev environment
   <br/><br/>
1. Install Docker

   Setup in Linux:

   ```
   sudo apt-get -y install docker-engine
   sudo usermod -aG docker $USER
   sudo reboot
   ```

   For other operating systems, please refer to the appropriate [Docker setup guide](https://docs.docker.com/get-docker/).

1. First, ensure that you have an AWS IAM role with access to the AEMP S3 bucket. In the root directory, create a `.env` file with your AWS credentials, using the following:

   ```
   AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=YOUR_ACCESS_KEY
   AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=YOUR_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY
   ```

1. Run the default Docker-Compose script. This will launch 3 containers: the UI, the api server, and a local Neo4j database
   for testing and development.

   ```
   docker-compose up
   ```

   `It is normal for this step to take several minutes`

   Once this completes, the app is available at `localhost:3000`, the Neo4J browser at `localhost:7474`, and the REST API at `localhost:4000/api`.

   For edits, tear downs, or re-builds `docker-compose down -V` and manually delete the _neo4j-import-done.flag_ file in the <u>_neo4j_data_</u> folder

### Troubleshooting

1. Missing Dependencies

- You may get a build-time error about missing depencencies occassionally
- This is normal when pulling down or switching to a branch that has new NPM dependencies that are not installed locally
- Running `NPM install` in a terminal will `NOT` work due to a virtual file system

  `Run these commands verbatim in the command line, while in the root project directory:`

      The UI or frontend container:

      docker-compose run ui npm install
      docker container restart ui


      The API or backend container:

      docker-compose run api npm install
      docker container restart api

2. If you encounter a `java.lang.RuntimeException` during start-up on the `neo4j_dev_db` container, you likely need to run `docker-compose down` before running `docker-compose up`.

3. **`react-app-rewired: not found` crash loop**

   See "Updating Dependencies" above. If all else fails, you _can_ nuke Docker completely by force stopping any active containers and then running a system prune:

   ```
   docker container stop $(docker container ls -aq)
   docker system prune -af --volumes
   ```

   This will remove _everything_ though, so be sure that's what you want.

4. If you still need help, feel free to post on Anti-Eviction Mapping Project Slack; someone is usually around to help.

### Prod Environment

1. Launch an EC2 instance running Ubuntu (e.g. Ubuntu 18.04)

1. Make sure the security group for the EC2 instance has port 3000 open

1. SSH into the instance

1. Install Docker (Linux)
   ```
   sudo apt-get -y install docker-engine
   sudo usermod -aG docker $USER
   sudo reboot
   ```
1. Export the test/production Neo4j endpoint as the environment variable `DB_ENDPOINT`.  
   Be sure it references a current neo4j instance. E.g.
   ```
   export DB_ENDPOINT=ec2-01-234-56-789.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com
   ```
   To remove the the environment variable (for example when switching back to a dev environment), unset it
   ```
   unset DB_ENDPOINT
   ```
1. Run the production Docker-Compose. This will launch 3 containers: the UI, the api server and the nginx webserver.
   ```
   docker-compose -f docker-compose.yml -f docker-compose.prod.yml up -d
   ```

### Using Test Database

In either the Development Environment or Production environment set-ups, you can optionally specify a Neo4j endpoint for use in testing experimental API queries. 

The main use case for this is during transitions between database verions -- the test database can be run on a remote EC2, and then in both local development and in the staging environment, the test queries will be run against the new database. Test queries should be integrated as the default queries before being pushed to the production instance, however.

To enable this, comment in the `NEO4J_URI_TEST` docker flag and export the test Neo4j endpoint as the environment variable `DB_ENDPOINT_TEST`. Be sure it references a current neo4j instance. E.g.
   ```
   export DB_ENDPOINT_TEST=ec2-01-234-56-789.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com
   ```

To disable using the test database, unset the environment variable.
   ```
   unset DB_ENDPOINT_TEST
   ```

appspec.app.yml

version: 0.0
os: linux
files:
  - source: /
    destination: /ebook
hooks:
  BeforeInstall:
    - location: deploy_scripts/app/stop.sh
      timeout: 3600
      runas: root
  ApplicationStart:
    - location: deploy_scripts/app/start.sh
      timeout: 3600
      runas: root

appspec.db.yml

version: 0.0
os: linux
files:
  - source: /
    destination: /ebook
hooks:
  BeforeInstall:
    - location: deploy_scripts/db/stop.sh
      timeout: 3600
      runas: root
  ApplicationStart:
    - location: deploy_scripts/db/start.sh
      timeout: 3600
      runas: root

deploy_scripts/app/prepare.sh

#!/bin/sh

apt-get install -y docker.io
# Debian package heavily deprecated, as usual.
curl -L https://github.com/docker/compose/releases/download/1.17.1/docker-compose-`uname -s`-`uname -m` -o /usr/local/bin/docker-compose
chmod +x /usr/local/bin/docker-compose
gpasswd -a ubuntu docker
newgrp docker
chown -R ubuntu:ubuntu /srv/arteria
yes | sudo apt install jq
yes | sudo apt install awscli

deploy_scripts/app/start.sh

#!/bin/bash

# ApplicationStart â€“ You typically use this deployment lifecycle event to restart services that were stopped during ApplicationStop.
# Let's Encrypt staging environment details can be found here: https://letsencrypt.org/docs/staging-environment/
echo "Start Container"
cd /ebook

# AWS vars
deployment_config_s3_path="s3://evictorbook/deployment_config.json"
deployment_config_file="deployment_config.json"

# Certbot vars
rsa_key_size=4096
certbot_data_path="./nginx_proxy/certbot"
email="tim@mappingaction.org" # Adding a valid address is strongly recommended

# Register AWS config
if [ -f $deployment_config_file ]; then
    rm $deployment_config_file
fi

aws s3 cp $deployment_config_s3_path $deployment_config_file

# Assign variables according to deployment type (staging or production)
if [ "$DEPLOYMENT_GROUP_NAME" == "staging" ]; then
    db_endpoint=$(jq -r '.Staging.Database.Endpoint' $deployment_config_file)
    nginx_conf_path="./nginx_proxy/nginx_staging"
    domains=(mac-staging.website)
    staging=1 # set to 1 for testing

elif [ "$DEPLOYMENT_GROUP_NAME" == "production" ]; then
    db_endpoint=$(jq -r '.Production.Database.Endpoint' $deployment_config_file)
    nginx_conf_path="./nginx_proxy/nginx_prod"
    domains=(evictorbook.com)
    staging=0 # set 0 for production
else
    echo "Invalid value for DEPLOYMENT_GROUP_NAME"
    exit 1
fi

# Environment vars used in docker-compose.prod.yml
export DB_ENDPOINT=$db_endpoint
export NGINX_CONF_PATH=$nginx_conf_path

# Get certbot params for setting up ssl/tls
function get_tls_parameters() {
    if [ ! -e "$certbot_data_path/conf/options-ssl-nginx.conf" ] || [ ! -e "$certbot_data_path/conf/ssl-dhparams.pem" ]; then
        echo "### Downloading recommended TLS parameters ..."
        mkdir -p "$certbot_data_path/conf"
        curl -s https://raw.githubusercontent.com/certbot/certbot/master/certbot-nginx/certbot_nginx/_internal/tls_configs/options-ssl-nginx.conf >"$certbot_data_path/conf/options-ssl-nginx.conf"
        curl -s https://raw.githubusercontent.com/certbot/certbot/master/certbot/certbot/ssl-dhparams.pem >"$certbot_data_path/conf/ssl-dhparams.pem"
        echo
    fi
}

# Create a dummy ssl certificate required to start Nginx
function create_dummy_cert() {
    echo "### Creating dummy certificate for $domains ..."
    path="/etc/letsencrypt/live/$domains"
    mkdir -p "$certbot_data_path/conf/live/$domains"
    docker-compose -f docker-compose.yml -f docker-compose.prod.yml run --rm --entrypoint "\
  openssl req -x509 -nodes -newkey rsa:1024 -days 1\
    -keyout '$path/privkey.pem' \
    -out '$path/fullchain.pem' \
    -subj '/CN=localhost'" certbot
    echo
}

# Compose staging/prod environment with dummy certificate
function compose_prod_env() {
    echo "### Composing detached production environment ..."
    docker-compose -f docker-compose.yml -f docker-compose.prod.yml up -d
    echo

    echo "### Recreating nginx ..."
    docker-compose -f docker-compose.yml -f docker-compose.prod.yml up --force-recreate -d nginx
    echo
}

# Delete dummy cert after starting staging/prod environment
function delete_dummy_cert() {
    echo "### Deleting dummy certificate for $domains ..."
    docker-compose -f docker-compose.yml -f docker-compose.prod.yml run --rm --entrypoint "\
  rm -Rf /etc/letsencrypt/live/$domains && \
  rm -Rf /etc/letsencrypt/archive/$domains && \
  rm -Rf /etc/letsencrypt/renewal/$domains.conf" certbot
    echo
}

# Replace deleted dummy cert with a letsencrypt cert and reload Nginx
function get_letsencrypt_cert() {

    echo "### Requesting Let's Encrypt certificate for $domains ..."
    #Join $domains to -d args
    domain_args=""
    for domain in "${domains[@]}"; do
        domain_args="$domain_args -d $domain"
    done

    # Select appropriate email arg
    case "$email" in
    "") email_arg="--register-unsafely-without-email" ;;
    *) email_arg="--email $email" ;;
    esac

    # Enable staging mode if needed
    if [ $staging != "0" ]; then staging_arg="--staging"; fi

    docker-compose -f docker-compose.yml -f docker-compose.prod.yml run --rm --entrypoint "\
  certbot certonly --webroot -w /var/www/certbot \
    $staging_arg \
    $email_arg \
    $domain_args \
    --rsa-key-size $rsa_key_size \
    --agree-tos \
    --non-interactive \
    --force-renewal" certbot
    echo

    echo "### Reloading nginx ..."
    docker-compose -f docker-compose.yml -f docker-compose.prod.yml exec -T nginx nginx -s reload
}

# Run phase
get_tls_parameters
create_dummy_cert
compose_prod_env
delete_dummy_cert
get_letsencrypt_cert

deploy_scripts/app/stop.sh

#!/bin/bash

echo "Stop Container"
cd /ebook
docker-compose -f docker-compose.yml -f docker-compose.prod.yml down --rmi 'all' --volumes
docker system prune --all --force --volumes
sudo rm -rf nginx_proxy/certbot/

deploy_scripts/db/prepare.sh

#!/bin/sh

apt-get install -y docker.io
# Debian package heavily deprecated, as usual.
curl -L https://github.com/docker/compose/releases/download/1.17.1/docker-compose-`uname -s`-`uname -m` -o /usr/local/bin/docker-compose
chmod +x /usr/local/bin/docker-compose
gpasswd -a ubuntu docker
newgrp docker
chown -R ubuntu:ubuntu /srv/arteria
yes | sudo apt install jq
yes | sudo apt install awscli

deploy_scripts/db/start.sh

#!/bin/bash

# ApplicationStart â€“ You typically use this deployment lifecycle event to restart services that were stopped during ApplicationStop.
# Let's Encrypt staging environment details can be found here: https://letsencrypt.org/docs/staging-environment/
echo "Start Container"
cd /ebook

# pull down the access keys for the AEMP `CodeDeploy` IAM (needed to download the db dump)
access_key_id=$(aws ssm get-parameters --region us-west-1 --names AEMP_CODE_DEPLOY_ACCESS_KEY_ID --with-decryption --query Parameters[0].Value | tr -d '"')
secret_access_key=$(aws ssm get-parameters --region us-west-1 --names AEMP_CODE_DEPLOY_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY --with-decryption --query Parameters[0].Value | tr -d '"' )

# now we can swap over to using env variables for the credentials (which will get passed to Docker config)
export AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=$access_key_id
export AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=$secret_access_key

docker-compose -f docker-compose.yml -f docker-compose.db-only.yml up -d

deploy_scripts/db/stop.sh

#!/bin/bash

echo "Stop Container"
cd /ebook

docker-compose down

# kill all running containers
docker kill $(docker ps -q)

# Delete every Docker containers
# Must be run first because images are attached to containers
docker rm -f $(docker ps -a -q)

# Delete every Docker image
docker rmi -f $(docker images -q)

docker system prune --all --force --volumes

# remove all networks
docker network prune -f

dev_scripts/update-ui-deps.sh

#!/bin/bash
cd "${0%/*}"
export PACKAGE_HASH=$(md5 -q ../ui/package.json)
export PACKAGE_LOCK_HASH=$(md5 -q ../ui/package-lock.json)
echo "Current package.json MD5 hash is $PACKAGE_HASH"
echo "Current package-lock.json MD5 hash is $PACKAGE_LOCK_HASH"
export CACHE_BUST="$PACKAGE_HASH:$PACKAGE_LOCK_HASH"
cd ../ui/
docker-compose stop ui
docker-compose build --build-arg CACHE_BUST=$CACHE_BUST ui
docker-compose up -d ui

docker-compose.db-only.yml

# Used to host the DB alone, used for deploying the db on a separate server in staging and 
# production environments.

# See /startup_scripts/neo4j-init.sh to see the version of the database loaded

version: "3.6"
services:
  neo4j:
      container_name: neo4j_db
      working_dir: /neo4j
      image: neo4j:4.2.2
      restart: unless-stopped
      ports:
        - "7474:7474"
        - "7473:7473"
        - "7687:7687"
      volumes: # don't mount /data or /logs https://github.com/neo4j/docker-neo4j/issues/131
        - ./startup_scripts:/startup_scripts
        - ./neo4j_data:/var/lib/neo4j/data
      environment:
        - EXTENSION_SCRIPT=/startup_scripts/neo4j-init.sh
        - NEO4JLABS_PLUGINS=["apoc", "graph-data-science"]
        - NEO4J_dbms_security_procedures_unrestricted=apoc.*,gds.*
        - NEO4J_AUTH=neo4j/admin
        - AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=${AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID}
        - AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=${AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY}

docker-compose.local-nodb.yaml

# docker-compose.local-nodb.yml
#
# docker config for local environments where there's already a neo4j container
# running at ${DB_ENDPOINT}. does *not* attempt to start another neo4j
# container.
#
# this allows for rapid development and testing of the node express backend
# server, without ever having to tear down or re-up the neo4j database server.
version: "3.6"
services:
  api:
    environment:
      - NEO4J_URI=bolt://${DB_ENDPOINT:-neo4j}:7687
      # optional flag to enable a second neo4j URI for testing (useful for transitions between API versions)
      # - NEO4J_TEST_URI=neo4j://${DB_ENDPOINT:-neo4j}:7687
      # debugging flags...
      # disable server memory-cache for testing:
      - EBOOK_API_DISABLE_CACHE=true
      # page size for /api/neighborhood:
      - EBOOK_API_NEIGHBORHOOD_MAX_PAGE_SIZE=100   # default:100
      # flags that impact the structure of api respones, use with care:
      - EBOOK_API_WRAP_NEIGHBORHOOD_EVICTIONS=false     # default:false
      - EBOOK_API_WRITE_PROTO_MULTIMAPS=false           # default:false
      - EBOOK_API_WRITE_JSON_SUBGRAPH_PROPERTIES=false  # default:false
      # experimental features:
      - EBOOK_API_ENABLE_UNIFIED_SEARCH=true

    command: ./startup_scripts/wait-for-it.sh ${DB_ENDPOINT}:7687 -t 180 -- node -r esm index.js

  ui:
    image: ui-dev
    container_name: ui-dev
    build:
      context: ./ui
      dockerfile: Dockerfile.dev
    restart: unless-stopped
    volumes:
      - ./ui:/home/node/app
      - ui_node_modules:/home/node/app/node_modules
      - ./startup_scripts:/home/node/app/startup_scripts
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
    command: ./startup_scripts/wait-for-it.sh ${DB_ENDPOINT}:7687 -t 180 -- npm start
    depends_on:
      - api
    tty: true
    stdin_open: true

docker-compose.override.yml

#docker-compose.override.yml
version: "3.6"
services:
  api:
    depends_on:
      - neo4j
    environment:
      - NEO4J_URI=neo4j://neo4j:7687
      # optional flag to enable a second neo4j URI for testing (useful for transitions between API versions)
      # - NEO4J_URI_TEST=neo4j://${DB_ENDPOINT_TEST}:7687
      # debugging flags...
      # server memory-cache control, set 'true' for testing:
      - EBOOK_API_DISABLE_CACHE=false # default:false
      # page size for /api/neighborhood:
      - EBOOK_API_NEIGHBORHOOD_MAX_PAGE_SIZE=100 # default:100
      # flags that impact the structure of REST respones, use with care:
      - EBOOK_API_WRAP_NEIGHBORHOOD_EVICTIONS=false # default:false
      - EBOOK_API_WRITE_PROTO_MULTIMAPS=false # default:false
      - EBOOK_API_WRITE_JSON_SUBGRAPH_PROPERTIES=false # default:false
      # experimental features:
      - EBOOK_API_ENABLE_UNIFIED_SEARCH=true
    command: ./startup_scripts/wait-for-it.sh ${DB_ENDPOINT:-neo4j}:7687 -t 180 -- node -r esm index.js

  ui:
    image: ui
    container_name: ui
    build:
      context: ./ui
      dockerfile: Dockerfile.dev
    restart: unless-stopped
    volumes:
      - ./ui:/home/node/app
      - ui_node_modules:/home/node/app/node_modules
      - ./startup_scripts:/home/node/app/startup_scripts
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
    command: ./startup_scripts/wait-for-it.sh ${DB_ENDPOINT:-neo4j}:7687 -t 180 -- npm start
    depends_on:
      - api
    tty: true
    stdin_open: true

  neo4j:
    container_name: neo4j_dev_db
    working_dir: /neo4j
    image: neo4j:4.2.2
    restart: unless-stopped
    ports:
      - "7474:7474"
      - "7473:7473"
      - "7687:7687"
    volumes: # don't mount /data or /logs https://github.com/neo4j/docker-neo4j/issues/131
      - ./startup_scripts:/startup_scripts
      - ./neo4j_data:/var/lib/neo4j/data
    environment:
      - EXTENSION_SCRIPT=/startup_scripts/neo4j-init.sh
      - NEO4JLABS_PLUGINS=["apoc", "graph-data-science"]
      - NEO4J_dbms_security_procedures_unrestricted=apoc.*,gds.*
      - NEO4J_AUTH=neo4j/admin
      - AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=${AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID}
      - AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=${AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY}

docker-compose.prod.yml

#docker-compose.prod.yml
version: "3.6"
services:
  nginx:
    image: nginx:1.18-alpine
    container_name: nginx
    restart: unless-stopped
    volumes:
      - ${NGINX_CONF_PATH}:/etc/nginx/conf.d
      - ./nginx_proxy/certbot/conf:/etc/letsencrypt
      - ./nginx_proxy/certbot/www:/var/www/certbot
    ports:
      - "80:80"
      - "443:443"
    command: '/bin/sh -c ''while :; do sleep 6h & wait $${!}; nginx -s reload; done & nginx -g "daemon off;"'''

  certbot:
    image: certbot/certbot
    container_name: certbot
    restart: unless-stopped
    volumes:
      - ./nginx_proxy/certbot/conf:/etc/letsencrypt
      - ./nginx_proxy/certbot/www:/var/www/certbot
    entrypoint: "/bin/sh -c 'trap exit TERM; while :; do certbot renew; sleep 12h & wait $${!}; done;'"

  api:
    environment:
      - NEO4J_URI=bolt://${DB_ENDPOINT}:7687
      # optional flag to enable a second neo4j URI for testing (useful for transitions between API versions)
      # - NEO4J_URI_TEST=neo4j://${DB_ENDPOINT_TEST}:7687
      # debug flags to control optional features...
      - EBOOK_API_ENABLE_UNIFIED_SEARCH=true
    command: ./startup_scripts/wait-for-it.sh ${DB_ENDPOINT}:7687 -t 30 -- node -r esm index.js

  ui:
    image: ui
    container_name: ui
    build:
      context: ./ui/
      dockerfile: Dockerfile
    restart: unless-stopped
    volumes:
      - ./ui:/home/node/app
      - ui_node_modules:/home/node/app/node_modules #weird
      - ./ui_log:/home/node/.npm/_logs
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
    depends_on:
      - api

docker-compose.yml

version: "3.6"
services:
  api:
    image: api
    container_name: api
    build:
      context: ./server
      dockerfile: Dockerfile
    restart: unless-stopped
    ports:
      - "4000:4000"
    environment:
      - NEO4J_USER=neo4j
      - NEO4J_PASSWORD=admin
      - REST_PORT=4000
      - DEV_SERVER=TRUE
      - UI_USERNAME=user
      - UI_PASSWORD=sftool
      - UI_TEMP_PASSWORD=temppass123
      - COOKIE_KEY=dsafs45adflk*37&^867KLHHJG
    volumes:
      - ./server:/home/node/app
      - api_node_modules:/home/node/app/node_modules
      - ./startup_scripts:/home/node/app/startup_scripts

volumes:
  api_node_modules:
  ui_node_modules:

nginx_proxy/nginx_prod/prod.conf

upstream ui {
    server ui:3000;
}

upstream api {
    server api:4000;
}

server {
    listen 80;
    server_name evictorbook.com;
    server_tokens off;

    location /.well-known/acme-challenge/ {
        root /var/www/certbot;
    }

    location / {
        return 301 https://$host$request_uri;
    }
}

server {

    listen 443 ssl;
    server_name evictorbook.com;
    server_tokens off;

    ssl_certificate /etc/letsencrypt/live/evictorbook.com/fullchain.pem;
    ssl_certificate_key /etc/letsencrypt/live/evictorbook.com/privkey.pem;
    include /etc/letsencrypt/options-ssl-nginx.conf;
    ssl_dhparam /etc/letsencrypt/ssl-dhparams.pem;

    location / {
        proxy_pass http://ui;
        proxy_set_header Host $http_host;
        proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
    }

    location /api {
        proxy_pass http://api;
    }

    location /session {
        proxy_pass http://api;
    }

    location /sockjs-node {
        proxy_pass http://ui;
        proxy_http_version 1.1;
        proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade;
        proxy_set_header Connection "Upgrade";
    }
}

nginx_proxy/nginx_staging/staging.conf

upstream ui {
    server ui:3000;
}

upstream api {
    server api:4000;
}

server {
    listen 80;
    server_name mac-staging.website;
    server_tokens off;

    location /.well-known/acme-challenge/ {
        root /var/www/certbot;
    }

    location / {
        return 301 https://$host$request_uri;
    }
}

server {

    listen 443 ssl;
    server_name mac-staging.website;
    server_tokens off;

    ssl_certificate /etc/letsencrypt/live/mac-staging.website/fullchain.pem;
    ssl_certificate_key /etc/letsencrypt/live/mac-staging.website/privkey.pem;
    include /etc/letsencrypt/options-ssl-nginx.conf;
    ssl_dhparam /etc/letsencrypt/ssl-dhparams.pem;

    location / {
        proxy_pass http://ui;
        proxy_set_header Host $http_host;
        proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
    }

    location /api {
        proxy_pass http://api;
    }

    location /session {
        proxy_pass http://api;
    }

    location /sockjs-node {
        proxy_pass http://ui;
        proxy_http_version 1.1;
        proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade;
        proxy_set_header Connection "Upgrade";
    }
}

package.json

server/.dockerignore

Dockerfile
.dockerignore

server/Dockerfile

FROM node:12.1.0

RUN mkdir -p /home/node/app/node_modules && chown -R node:node /home/node/app

WORKDIR /home/node/app

# A wildcard is used to ensure both package.json AND package-lock.json are copied
COPY package*.json ./

USER node

# expose the server port
EXPOSE 4000

## install only the packages defined in the package-lock.json (faster than the normal npm install)
RUN npm install

server/backends/neo4jBackend.js

// neo4jBackend.js
//
// wrapper for the neo4j-driver module. this module returns a function which,
// when called, instantiates a neo4j driver object with the passed-in config.
//
// this allows the api server to maintain connections to multiple different
// neo4j database servers.
//
// avoid redundant calls to this function. since it creates a new driver object
// each time it's called, only call it during app setup and only once per
// target database.
//
// usage: 
//   create a driver obj with default options:
//     const db-driver = neo4jBackend();
//
//   create a driver object with custom options:
//     const db-driver-test = neo4jBackend({ use_test_endpoint: true });
//
// see below for a description of the supported properties in 'options'.

import neo4j from 'neo4j-driver';
import flagUtils from '../framework/flagUtils';

// define flags...
const flags = {};

// note: as of v2 database, uses neo4j version 4, and should be addressed with the
// 'neo4j://' uri scheme.
flagUtils.defineStringEnvFlag(flags, 'neo4j_uri', process.env.NEO4J_URI, 'neo4j://localhost:7687');

flagUtils.defineStringEnvFlag(flags, 'neo4j_uri_test', process.env.NEO4J_URI_TEST, 'neo4j://neo4j:7687');
flagUtils.defineStringEnvFlag(flags, 'neo4j_user', process.env.NEO4J_USER);
flagUtils.defineStringEnvFlag(flags, 'neo4j_password', process.env.NEO4J_PASSWORD);

// main exported function.
//
// if supplied, 'options' param is an object that supports the following
// properties: 
//   {
//     // if set true, use 'neo4j_uri_test' from flags. if unset or false, use
//     // the 'neo4j_uri' flag instead.
//     use_test_endpoint: <boolean>
//   }
const neo4jBackend = function(options = {}) {
  let neo4jUri = ( options.use_test_endpoint
                   ? flags.neo4j_uri_test
                   : flags.neo4j_uri );

  // via db-driver.js:
  const driver = neo4j.driver(
    neo4jUri,
    neo4j.auth.basic(
      flags.neo4j_user,
      flags.neo4j_password),
    { disableLosslessIntegers: true });

  return driver;
}

export default neo4jBackend;

server/flags/dbRouteFlags.js

import flagUtils from '../framework/flagUtils';

// container obj for command-line flags, to be exported.
//
// - top-level setup functions can import this file directly and use the results.
//
// - modules which need to be run in unit tests should access these flags by
//     passing the exported dbRouteFlags object via app.locals.
const dbRouteFlags = {};

// define flags...

// if set true, enable API routes that will query the remote testing DB under '/api/test/...'
// this is useful when transitioning between database versions that will require
// changes to the API. This allows for simultaneous access to the existing routes
// and experimental, testing routes

//   default: false
flagUtils.defineBooleanEnvFlag(
    dbRouteFlags, 'enable_test',
    process.env.NEO4J_URI_TEST, false);

// if set true, enable unified search api at '/api/search?q=foo'
//   default: true
flagUtils.defineBooleanEnvFlag(
    dbRouteFlags, 'enable_unified_search',
    process.env.EBOOK_API_ENABLE_UNIFIED_SEARCH, true);

// if set true, validate query responses with json-schema definitions.
// NOTE: Before activating this, need to verify that all fields which may
// possibly be 'null' are represented as 'nullable'.
// See https://github.com/antievictionmappingproject/evictorbook/issues/408
//   default: false
flagUtils.defineBooleanEnvFlag(
    dbRouteFlags, 'validate_query_responses',
    process.env.EBOOK_API_VALIDATE_QUERY_RESPONSES, false);

// if set true, disable cacheMiddleware for db routes. useful for rapid testing
// in development environment. DON'T DO THIS IN PRODUCTION.
//
//   default: false
flagUtils.defineBooleanEnvFlag(
    dbRouteFlags, 'disable_cache', process.env.EBOOK_API_DISABLE_CACHE, false);

// TODO(Dana): Deprecate this flag and delete.
//
// if set true, response json matches rest proto, where multimap fields are
// represented as maps of '{ value: <list_of_strings> }' objects.
//
// otherwise, response json matches the may 2020 api, where multimap fields
// are represented directly as maps of lists.
//
// context: may 2020 api responses include maps of lists, which are not
// supported in proto. to get proto compatibility, we represent those fields
// instead as a proto map of StringVector messages.
//
//   default: false
flagUtils.defineBooleanEnvFlag(
    dbRouteFlags, 'write_proto_multimaps',
    process.env.EBOOK_API_WRITE_PROTO_MULTIMAPS, false);

// TODO(Dana): Deprecate this flag and delete.
//
// if set true, /api/network/... response json encodes graph node's properties
// as a json-encoded string named 'properties_json'.
//
// otherwise, /api/network/... response json features node properties as a
// plain obj named 'properties'. this matches the may 2020 api behavior.
//
// context: when encoding getNetworkParcel and getNetworkBE responses as
// proto, we provide a json blob of node properties rather than attempting to fully
// document the graph schema inside rest response proto. this is a good way to
// approximate the behavior of the original rest api (and the neo4j-driver api
// it's based on), while still a valid type-safe proto.
//
// see type_definitions/proto/rest/graph_util.proto
//
//   default: false
flagUtils.defineBooleanEnvFlag(
  dbRouteFlags, 'write_subgraph_properties_json',
  process.env.EBOOK_API_WRITE_JSON_SUBGRAPH_PROPERTIES, false);

// TODO: Rename to 'default' instead of 'max'.
//
// if set, use this as the default page size allowed for /api/neighborhood/...
// requests. (when page size is not specified, /api/neighborhood uses the
// maximum by default.)
//
//   default: 100
flagUtils.defineIntegerEnvFlag(
  dbRouteFlags, 'neighborhood_max_page_size',
  process.env.EBOOK_API_NEIGHBORHOOD_MAX_PAGE_SIZE, 100);

// TODO(Dana): Deprecate this flag and delete.
//
// if set true, /api/neighborhood/... response json represents
// { evictions: <list> }. this allows compatibility with response proto in
// rest/ebook_service.proto
//
// otherwise, response json represents a list of evictions with no wrapper
// object, as in the may 2020 production server.
//
//   default: false
flagUtils.defineBooleanEnvFlag(
  dbRouteFlags, 'wrap_neighborhood_evictions',
  process.env.EBOOK_API_WRAP_NEIGHBORHOOD_EVICTIONS, false);

// export the flags object.
export default dbRouteFlags;

server/framework/README.md

Framework

Previously located in server/inc/pocket-dimension.

The files in this directory contain code that was conceived of as a general-purpose framework I call 'pocket-dimension', intended to be re-used for other projects. Express is an impressive framework, but it's missing certain utilities and conveniences that I've found necessary for readable and maintainable web applications, so I implemented this to fill in the gaps. I developed this in parallel with my work on the ebook web server, using evictorbook as a test case to verify that this would be useful in a real-world system.

As such, I isolated this code into a separate folder in the project and labeled it with that project's name to distinguish it from the ebook application itself.

Some elements turned out to be extremely useful for ebook's use cases (safe and readable debug flag access, mock app harness for testing). Other elements, in practice, were more narrow or specialized than a project like ebook calls for ('service' metaphor for reusing code between client-facing and internal code, validation utilities for schemas written in 'protocol buffer' language.)

As I depart the project, I'm performing a cleanup pass and moving the code from 'inc/pocket-dimension/' to the more legible 'framework/'. These are tools that I've found to be quite useful in general, and future maintainers are encouraged to make use of these modules and update them as the need arises. Consider the code in this directory the 'aemp' fork of my mini-framework, here if you ever need it.

The original README from 3/2021 is preserved below. 

-Dana

pocket-dimension: a toolkit by datagram

tools for writing simple and effective node.js servers in express. there are two main components: 

- utilities for using protocol buffers to type-check plain javascript objects. useful for enforcing type-checks on rest payloads, database query results, or other data types where there's an implicit schema that could benefit from more rigorous definition.
- utilities for writing modular, stateless rest handlers in node express. first-class support for dependency injection via app.locals context, safe accessors for shell environment variables, more to come.

taken together, this toolkit allows for systems programmers to adopt a modular and flexible approach for stateless real-time backend systems in the javascript language.

note: the target platform for this library is node. however, the functions in protoUtils are intended to be appropriate for use in-browser, as well. (for example, a react client could call protoUtils.checkProto() to verify the field names and structure of rest-json payloads received from a server api.)


written and maintained by datagram.

server/framework/flagUtils.js

// flagUtils.js


// helper functions to read flags from env:

// safe way to read a boolean flag, passed to the app via env variable.
//
// inputs: string value of an env variable, and the intended default. return
// true if the string is "true", and false if the string is "false". otherwise,
// return the otherwise, return the default.
//
// recommended: prefer variables that default to false. they're safer.
//
// usage:
//    const debugFlag = readBooleanEnvFlag(process.env.ENV_VARIABLE, false);
//    if (debugFlag) {
//      // do something you don't normally do in production.
//    }
export function readBooleanEnvFlag(envString, defaultValue = false) {
  if (envString === "true") { return true; }
  if (envString === "false") { return false; }
  return defaultValue;
}

// safe way to read an integer flag, passed to the app via env variable.
//
// inputs: string value of the env variable, and the intended integer default.
// if the string can be parsed as an integer, return that integer value.
// otherwise, returns the default. ('' -> default, not zero.)
//
// usage:
//   const someParam = readIntegerEnvFlag(process.env.ENV_VARIABLE, 100);
//   if (someParam < 0) {
//     callSomeFunction(someParam);
//   }
export function readIntegerEnvFlag(envString, defaultValue = 0) {
  var value;
  if (!envString) {
    // return default if undefined/empty str is passed in...
    return defaultValue;
  }
  value = Number(envString);
  if (!Number.isInteger(value)) {
    // ...or if the number is a non-integer.
    return defaultValue;
  }
  return value;
}

// safe way to read a string flag, passed into the app via env variable.
//
// inputs: the value of an env variable, as returned by process.env.MY_VARIABLE,
//  and an intended default value.
//
// usage:
//   const someValue = readStringEnvFlag(process.env.MY_VARIABLE, "tubular");
//
// this isn't as useful as the equivalent helper functions for boolean and
// number flags, but it's here for symmetry.
export function readStringEnvFlag(envString, defaultValue = '') {
  return ( envString ? envString : defaultValue );
}

// internal helper function, check types and throw a well-formatted error if
// param_value's type doesn't match expected_typename.
//
// example usage:
//   checkParamType("flags", flags, 'object');
//
// if 'print_value' is true, include param_value's value in the error msg.
// if 'check_nonfalse' is true, also throw on 'if (!param_value)'.
const checkParamType = function(
    param_name, param_value, expected_typename,
    print_value = true, check_nonfalse = false) {
  if (typeof param_value !== expected_typename) {
    throw 'invalid ' + param_name + ',' + 
        ' expected ' + expected_typename + ',' +
        ' found: ' + typeof param_value +
        ( (print_value) ? (', value: ' + param_value) : '' );
  }
  if (check_nonfalse && (!param_value)) {
    throw 'invalid ' + param_name + ',' + 
        ' expected non-falsey ' + expected_typename + ',' +
        ' found: ' + typeof param_value +
        ( (print_value) ? (', value: ' + param_value) : '' );
  }
}

// safely read and store a boolean flag, passed to the app via env variable.
//
// inputs:
//   flags: object. value will be stored as a property of this obj.
//   flagName: a name for your flag. access the value later at flags.flagName.
//   envString: the string-value of an environment variable to process, as
//       retrieved with 'process.env.ENV_VARIABLE'.
//   defaultValue: if supplied, the boolean value to use by default.
//
// example usage:
//   // in app setup...
//   const flags = {};
//   defineBooleanEnvFlag(flags, 'myFlag', process.env.MY_ENV_VARIABLE, false);
//
//   // ... later ...
//   if (flags.myFlag) {
//     // do something you don't normally do in production.
//   }
export function defineBooleanEnvFlag(
    flags, flagName, envString = '', defaultValue = false) {
  checkParamType('flags', flags, 'object');
  checkParamType('flagName', flagName, 'string', true, true);
  checkParamType('envString', envString, 'string', true, false);
  checkParamType('defaultValue', defaultValue, 'boolean');

  Object.defineProperty(flags, flagName, {
    value: readBooleanEnvFlag(envString, defaultValue),
    writable: false
  });
}

// safely read and store an integer flag, passed to the app via env variable.
//
// inputs:
//   flags: object. value will be stored as a property of this obj.
//   flagName: a name for your flag. access the value later at flags.flagName.
//   envString: the string-value of an environment variable to process, as
//       retrieved with 'process.env.ENV_VARIABLE'.
//   defaultValue: if supplied, the integer value to use by default.
//
// example usage:
//   // in app setup...
//   const flags = {};
//   defineIntegerEnvFlag(flags, 'myParam', process.env.MY_ENV_VARIABLE, 192);
//
//   // ... later ...
//   const someParam = flags.myParam;  // default: 192.
//   if (someParam < 0) {
//     callSomeFunction(someParam);
//   }
export function defineIntegerEnvFlag(
    flags, flagName, envString = '', defaultValue = 0) {
  checkParamType('flags', flags, 'object');
  checkParamType('flagName', flagName, 'string', true, true);
  checkParamType('envString', envString, 'string', true, false);
  checkParamType('defaultValue', defaultValue, 'number');

  if (!Number.isInteger(defaultValue)) {
    throw 'bad default value, expected integer, got: ' + defaultValue;
  }

  Object.defineProperty(flags, flagName, {
    value: readIntegerEnvFlag(envString, defaultValue),
    writable: false
  });
}

// safely read and store a string flag, passed to the app via env variable.
//
// inputs:
//   flags: object. value will be stored as a property of this obj.
//   flagName: a name for your flag. access the value later at flags.flagName.
//   envString: the string-value of an environment variable to process, as
//       retrieved with 'process.env.ENV_VARIABLE'.
//   defaultValue: if supplied, the string value to use by default.
//
// example usage:
//   // in app setup...
//   const flags = {};
//   defineStringEnvFlag(flags, 'myFlag', process.env.MY_ENV_VARIABLE, 'mondo');
//
//   // ... later ...
//   if (flags.myFlag !== "mondo") {
//     // do something you don't normally do in production.
//   }
export function defineStringEnvFlag(
    flags, flagName, envString = '', defaultValue = '') {
  checkParamType('flags', flags, 'object');
  checkParamType('flagName', flagName, 'string', true, true);
  checkParamType('envString', envString, 'string', true, false);
  checkParamType('defaultValue', defaultValue, 'string');

  Object.defineProperty(flags, flagName, {
    value: readStringEnvFlag(envString, defaultValue),
    writable: false
  });
}

export default {
  defineBooleanEnvFlag,
  defineIntegerEnvFlag,
  defineStringEnvFlag,
  readBooleanEnvFlag,
  readIntegerEnvFlag,
  readStringEnvFlag
};

server/framework/mockApp.js

// mockApp.js
//
// helper functions useful for testing rest listeners.

// creates fake versions of the express app objects, to serve as harness for
// rest listeners under test.
export function expressMocks() {
  // placeholder obj for mocks to store info from code under test (response
  // values, other internal details) so they can be verified by unit tests.
  //   usage:
  //     var mocks = mockUtils.expressMocks();
  //     mocks.req.app.locals.queryHandlers["label"] = fakeQueryHandler;
  //     await restListenerUnderTest(mocks.req, mocks.resp);
  //
  //     // now, you can assert() to validate response.
  //     var actualResponse = JSON.parse(mocks.actuals.response_body);
  //     assert(...);
  //
  // NOTE: query handler callbacks may set additional properties here, when
  // invoked, to pass detailed information back to test harness for
  // assertions (verify parsing of input params, etc.)
  const actuals = {
    response_body: "",          // set on resp.json() or resp.send()
    response_finalized: false,  // set true on resp.json() or resp.send()
    response_code: 200          // set on resp.status()
  };

  // mock request obj, lets code under test know about request parameters and
  // app locals.
  const req = {
    // caller should set route params here for code under test.
    params: {},
    // mock app context. express presents the 'app' obj to callers as a
    // property of 'req'. we take advantage of this to inject dependencies
    // and flags into listeners under test.
    app: {
      locals: {
        // mock query handler callbacks, insert a callback with the
        // appropriate label to provide data to code under test. handler
        // callbacks must be async. see details in opening comments of
        // dbRouteListeners.js.
        queryHandlers: {},
        // mock flags, set these to configure listener behavior.
        //
        // !!! IMPORTANT !!!:
        // if code under test relies on non-falsey defaults for flags
        // (integer values), you MUST set that default value in your test.
        // TODO: import non-falsey defaults from app setup.
        dbRouteFlags: {}
      }
    }
  };

  // mock response obj, sent to code under test.
  const resp = {
    // mock 'json' function, writes stringified obj to actuals.
    json: function(response_obj) {
      if (actuals.response_finalized) { throw 'redundant json() call!'; }
      actuals.response_body = JSON.stringify(response_obj);
      actuals.response_finalized = true;
      return resp;
    },
    // mock 'send' function, writes response body string to actuals.
    send: function(response_body) {
      if (actuals.response_finalized) { throw 'redundant send() call!'; }
      actuals.response_body = response_body;
      actuals.response_finalized = true;
      return resp;
    },
    // mock 'status' function, writes given http status code to actuals.
    status: function(code) {
      if (actuals.response_finalized) { throw 'redundant status() call!'; }
      actuals.response_code = code;
      return resp;
    }
  };

  return {
    actuals: actuals,
    req: req,
    resp: resp
  };
}

export default {
  expressMocks
};

server/framework/protoTestUtils.js

// protoTestUtils.js
//
// test-specific functions for checking types with protocol buffers.

var assert = require('assert');
var Pbf = require('pbf');

var protoUtils = require('./protoUtils');

// assert that obj1 and obj2 are both valid protos, and that they represent
// equivalent proto messages.
//
// TODO: catch err's and assert, rather than throwing errs back to caller.
export function assertProtoEquivalence(protoDesc, obj1, obj2) {
  // verify obj's are valid as proto. (correct types, no extra fields).
  protoUtils.checkProto(protoDesc, obj1);
  protoUtils.checkProto(protoDesc, obj2);

  // encode and reinflate, to standardize / add defaults.
  var reinflated1 = protoUtils.encodeAndReinflate(protoDesc, obj1);
  var reinflated2 = protoUtils.encodeAndReinflate(protoDesc, obj2);

  assert.deepStrictEqual(reinflated1, reinflated2);
}

export default {
  assertProtoEquivalence
};

server/framework/protoUtils.js

// protoUtils.js
//
// functions for checking types with protocol buffers, via Pbf proto modules.

var Pbf = require('pbf');
var RecursiveDiff = require('recursive-diff');
var path = require('path');
var resolve = require('resolve-protobuf-schema');
var compile = require('pbf/compile');

// Resolves dependencies and compiles a protocol buffer schema from a .proto file.
// Heavily inspired by the mapbox pbf compiler cli:
// https://github.com/mapbox/pbf/blob/master/bin/pbf
//
// Note that the filename provided must be presented relative to the root
// directory of the project.
//
// ex: if proto schema is in '<app_root>/schemas/proto/', then you should
// provide 'schemas/proto/example.proto', *NOT* the relative path from your js
// file such as '../../schemas/proto/example.proto or similar.
//
// This is due to implementation details of node's 'resolve-protobuf-schema'.
export function compileProto(filename) {
  const filepath = path.resolve(filename);
  return compile(resolve.sync(filepath));
}

// given a plain obj and a Pbf proto message, encode that obj as a proto and then
// reinflate it to a new plain object. new object is a deep copy; the original
// object is untouched.
//
// the new object is a deep copy of the original except:
//    - unrecognized properties are discarded.
//    - matching properties are retained.
//    - unset properties are intialized with their default proto values.
//
// throws err if things go wrong.
export function encodeAndReinflate(protoDesc, obj) {
  try {
    var pbf = new Pbf();
    protoDesc.write(obj, pbf);
    var finished_buffer = pbf.finish();
    var refilledPbf = new Pbf(finished_buffer);

    return protoDesc.read(refilledPbf);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("encodeAndReinflate err: " + err);
    throw "couldn't write/read obj. invalid proto description?";
  }
};

// given a Pbf module proto description, create a plain obj with properties
// initialized to the fieldnames and default values of that proto.
//
// throws err if things go wrong.
export function emptyObjFromProto(protoDesc) {
  try {
    return protoDesc.read(new Pbf());
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("emptyObjFromProto err: " + err);
    throw "couldn't read proto. invalid proto description?";
  }
};

// check if a plain obj conforms to a Pbf module proto description.
//
// if the object conforms to proto, we return nothing (undefined).
// if the object doesn't conform to proto, or can't be verified, throws err.
//
// rules for conformance:
//   - all obj's properties must have a name and type that matches a
//       correponding field in the proto message definition.
//   - no extraneous properties may be set.
//   - obj is allowed to have missing/unset properties (exception: fields
//       marked 'required' in proto must be set. don't do this -- use of
//       required fields in proto is STRONGLY discouraged.)
//   - obj properties may be set to default values that correspond to their
//       default values. (strings can be '', objects can be null, booleans can
//       be false, int's can be 0, etc. (assuming proto3 syntax)).
//
//  protos are checked recursively, so embedded message field obj's must also
//  pass checks for their proto defs, and so on for embedded message fields of
//  those obj's.
//
// example usage:
//   try {
//     checkProto(MyProto.SomeMessage, obj);
//   } catch (err) {
//     console.log("type error, failed proto check: " + err);
//     return;
//   }
export function checkProto(protoDesc, obj) {
  try {
    // generate another plain object by encoding and reinflating obj as
    // proto. the result will have the following properties:
    //   1. field names and default values set;
    //   2. fields populated in obj remain populated;
    //   3. extraneous fields not part of proto definition are removed.
    var reinflated = encodeAndReinflate(protoDesc, obj);  // might throw.

    // getDiff returns a list of all differences found. empty list means the
    // two objects are deeply equal. the objects are compared 'left to right',
    // order of arguments is important because diff returns more info about additions than deletions.
    //
    // allowed diffs (comparing reinflated ---> obj):
    //   'deleted' paths: ok. any properties missing from 'obj' were added
    //     during reinflate, so they are proto default values.
    //   'added' paths: unrecognized properties, never allowed.
    //      TODO: consider adding an option for non-strict comparison, allowing
    //      extra properties.
    //   'updated' paths: valid path name, but value was rejected by proto.
    //     allow only when the obj value is equivalent to the proto default (ex:
    //     null instead of '' for a string value).
    var diff = RecursiveDiff.getDiff(reinflated, obj);

    // debugging: set true to enable verbose logging for debugging.
    // set back to false before submitting.
    if (false) {
      console.log("DEBUG: obj " + JSON.stringify(reinflated));
      console.log("DEBUG: reinflated " + JSON.stringify(reinflated));
      console.log("DEBUG: diff " + JSON.stringify(diff));
    }

    for (var diff_ind in diff) {
      var d = diff[diff_ind];
      if (d.op === "delete") {
        continue;
      }
      else if (d.op === "update") {
        // context: neo4j driver objects have null for unset strings, while
        // proto string fields default to '', so we allow null as a proxy for
        // proto defaults.
        if (d.val === null) {
          continue;
        }
        // otherwise...
        throw "unexpected value: " + d.val + " at path: " +
          JSON.stringify(d.path);
      }
      else if (d.op === "add") {
        throw "unexpected property path: " + JSON.stringify(d.path);
      }
    }
    // nothing to return.
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("checkProto err: " + err);
    throw err;
  }
};

// Returns a validator function, to be used with the pocket-dimension service
// interface. The returned function takes one plain obj parameter, and returns
// true if the obj conforms to the protocol buffer schema expressed by the
// pbfEncoder obj, false otherwise. Never throws.
export function buildPbfValidatorFn(pbfEncoder) {
  return function(obj) {
    try {
      checkProto(pbfEncoder, obj)
    } catch (err) {
      return false;
    }
    return true;
  }
}

export default {
  compileProto,
  checkProto,
  emptyObjFromProto,
  encodeAndReinflate,
  buildPbfValidatorFn
};

server/framework/serviceUtils.js

// serviceUtils.js
import protoUtils from  './protoUtils';
import statusUtils from './statusUtils';

// Invokes a local service call without explicit type-checking.
// never throws.
//
// - app is the express 'app' object.
// - handlerFn is a function which takes (app, request_data, response_data),
//     populates response_data, and returns a status object, of the type
//     created by the helper methods in ./statusUtils.js
// - request_data is a plain object representing the request data payload. it
//     should conform to the protocol of the RPC's "Request" message.
// - response_data, if supplied, will be passed in to handlerFn and used to
//     contain the data payload of the response. it is the same object which
//     appears in the 'data' property of the return value.
const invokeFlexibleLocalRpcHandler = async function(
    app, handlerFn, request_data, response_data = {}) {
  let response_status;  // to contain status, error codes, etc.
  try {
    response_status = await handlerFn(app, request_data, response_data);
  } catch (err) {
    // TODO: Do something less hokey for error handling.
    console.error("error invoking local service: ", err);
    return { error: { status: statusUtils.internalErrorStatus() } };
  }

  // if the invocation was successful, return response_data directly (no wrapper).
  // (if rpcHandler returned nothing, assume status 'OK'.)
  if (!response_status || statusUtils.isStatusOk(response_status)) {
    return response_data;
  }

  // if we're here, then the handler fn returned an obj that's not an 'OK'
  // status.
  if (!Number.isInteger(response_status.code)) {
    // malformed response status, return INTERNAL_ERROR.
    console.error("error invoking local service; malformed response status: " +
      JSON.stringify(response_status));
    return { error: { status: statusUtils.internalErrorStatus() } };
  }

  // handler returned a well-formed status representing an error, return it to
  // the caller in an 'error' wrapper.
  return { error: { status: response_status } };
}

// Invoke a local rpc handler, and confirm that the input and output payloads
// return 'true' when passed to their respective validator functions (if present).
//
// Throws an error if either the passed-in request_data or the populated
// response_data breaks from the expected message protocol.
const invokeLocalRpcHandler = async function(
    app, handlerFn, request_validator_fn, response_validator_fn,
    request_data, response_data = {}) {
  // ensure that the request_data conforms to expected message protocol.
  if (request_validator_fn) {
    try {
      if (!request_validator_fn(request_data)) {
        console.error("Caller supplied invalid request data: ", err);
        return { error: { status: statusUtils.badRequestStatus() } };
      }
    } catch (err) {
      // Encountered an exception when attempting to validate.
      console.error("Error when trying to validate request data: ", err);
      return { error: { status: statusUtils.internalErrorStatus() } };
    }
  }

  const response_or_error = await invokeFlexibleLocalRpcHandler(
      app, handlerFn, request_data, response_data);

  // Uncomment to see well-formatted json in the logs for each invoked rpc
  // method. Good for demos, good for debugging.
  // console.error("DEBUGGING: ret: " + JSON.stringify(ret, null, 2));

  // When the call is successful, 'response_or_error' refers to the exact same
  // object as 'response_data'.
  if (response_or_error == response_data) {
    if (response_validator_fn) {
      try {
        if (!response_validator_fn(response_data)) {
          console.error("Caller supplied invalid response data: ", err);
          return { error: { status: statusUtils.internalErrorStatus() } };
        }
      } catch (err) {
        // Encountered an exception when attempting to validate.
        console.error("Error when trying to validate response data: ", err);
        return { error: { status: statusUtils.internalErrorStatus() } };
      }
    }
    return response_data;
  }

  // if we're here, the call invocation returned something other than the
  // response_data object, which means we're meant to interpret it as a plain
  // obj, which should have an 'error' property that's a plain status obj.
  if (!response_or_error.error
      || !response_or_error.error.status
      || !response_or_error.error.status.code) {
    // error obj was malformed, return an INTERNAL_ERROR instead.
    console.error("error invoking local service (type-safe); malformed response status: " +
      JSON.stringify(response_status));
    return { error: { status: statusUtils.internalErrorStatus() } };
  }

  // if we're here, the call invocation returned a well-formed error wrapper
  // obj. return it to the caller.
  return response_or_error;
}

// Invokes a service call locally, based on the info in the passed-in service
// obj. If the service obj contains a description of the message protocol to be
// used for the given method's request and response payloads, then those
// message protocols are enforced with checkProto.
//
// Example usage:
//   let result = await invokeLocalServiceCall(
//       app, queryService, "BusinessEntityIndexSearch", request_data);
//   if (result.meta.status.code !== 200) {
//     // bad. throw error.
//   }
//   let response_data = result.data;
const invokeLocalServiceCall = async function(
    app, service, methodName, request_data, response_data = {}) {
  return invokeLocalRpcHandler(
    app,
    service.handlers[methodName],
    service.requestValidators[methodName],
    service.responseValidators[methodName],
    request_data, response_data);
}

// To be called during app setup. Example usage:
//
// const service = {};
// registerHandlerCallback(
//   service, "ParcelIndexSearch", parcelSearchFn,
//   parcelSearchRequestValidatorFn, parcelSearchResponseValidatorFn);
// // and so on for other methods on the service....
//
// request_validator_fn and request_encoder_fn are functions which will be
// invoked with a single plain obj parameter, the request_data or response_data
// of a service call (respectively).
//
// If supplied, the validator functions must return a boolean -- true if the
// data passes validation, false otherwise.
//
// To generate a flexible (non-type-safe) service handler, invoke this function
// without specifying request_validator_fn or response_validator_fn.
const registerHandlerCallback = function(service, methodName, handlerFn,
    request_validator_fn = null, response_validator_fn = null) {
  if (!methodName || typeof methodName !== "string") {
    throw "expected non-empty string methodName, found: " + methodName;
  }
  if (!service.handlers) { service.handlers = {}; }
  if (!service.requestValidators) { service.requestValidators = {}; }
  if (!service.responseValidators) { service.responseValidators = {}; }

  // TODO: Set these in such a way that they can't be overwritten.
  service.handlers[methodName] = handlerFn;
  if (request_validator_fn) {
    service.requestValidators[methodName] = request_validator_fn;
  }
  if (response_validator_fn) {
    service.responseValidators[methodName] = response_validator_fn;
  }
}


// Given a result value returned from an 'invoke' function above, return true
// if the result represents a response_data payload from a successful call.
// Return false otherwise.
const isResultOk = function(result) {
  if (!result) return false;
  if (typeof result !== "object") return false;
  if (result.error) return false;

  return true;
}

// Returns a convenient object wrapper for the service functionality defined
// above, to provide a terser syntax for callers.
//
// usage:
// during application setup:
//   const handler = buildServiceHandler("FooService");
//   handler.registerCallback("Method1", method1Handler, ...);
//   
// later:
//   const result_or_error = await handler.invoke(app, "Method1", request_data);
//   if (!isResultOk(result_or_error)) {
//     // Handle error and return.
//     return;
//   }
//   // If you're here, result_or_error contains the response_data as set by
//   // the service's method2Handler callback fn.
const buildServiceHandler = function(serviceName) {
  return {
    name: serviceName,
    invoke: function(app, methodName, request_data, response_data) {
      return invokeLocalServiceCall(app, this, methodName, request_data, response_data);
    },
    registerCallback: function(
        methodName, handlerFn, request_validator_fn, response_validator_fn) {
      return registerHandlerCallback(
        this, methodName, handlerFn, request_validator_fn, response_validator_fn);
    }
  }
}

export default {
  invokeFlexibleLocalRpcHandler,
  invokeLocalRpcHandler,
  invokeLocalServiceCall,
  registerHandlerCallback,
  isResultOk,
  buildServiceHandler
};

server/framework/statusUtils.js

// statusUtils.js

// Creates a 'status' object used to represent a successful call.
const okStatus = function() {
  return { code: 200 }
}

// Creates a 'status' object used to represent an error case, with a numeric
// code and an optional string message.
const errorStatus = function(code, message) {
  if (!Number.isInteger(code)) {
    throw "expected integer code, found: " + code;
  }

  if (message && typeof message !== "string") {
    throw "expected string message, found: " + message
  }

  const ret = { code: code };
  if (message) {
    ret.message = message;
  }
  return ret;
}

// Creates a 'status' object representing 'Bad Request' (code 400), with an
// optional string message.
const badRequestStatus = function(message) {
  if (!message) { message = "BAD_REQUEST"; }
  return errorStatus(400, message);
}

// Creates a 'status' object representing 'Internal Error' (code 500), with an
// optional string message.
const internalErrorStatus = function(message) {
  if (!message) { message = "INTERNAL_ERROR"; }
  return errorStatus(500, message);
}

// Creates a 'status' object representing 'Not Implemented' (code 501), with an
// optional string message.
const notImplementedStatus = function(message) {
  if (!message) { message = "NOT_IMPLEMENTED"; }
  return errorStatus(501, message);
}

// Returns true if the status obj represents an 'OK' status, false otherwise.
const isStatusOk = function(status) {
  if (!status) return false;
  return status.code === 200;
}

export default {
  okStatus,
  errorStatus,
  badRequestStatus,
  internalErrorStatus,
  notImplementedStatus,
  isStatusOk
}

server/index.js

// import dotenv from 'dotenv'; //replace with docker compose env
import express from 'express';
import rest from './rest/server/rest';

// Set environment variables from .env
// dotenv.config();
//constants from .env
//const REST_PORT = process.env.REST_LISTEN_PORT;
const REST_PORT = process.env.REST_PORT; // from Docker instead of .env
const COOKIE_KEY = process.env.COOKIE_KEY;

//servers
const restApp = express();

//servers
rest(restApp, COOKIE_KEY, REST_PORT);

server/rest/handlers/query/about/assessor.js

// about/assessor.js

const query = `
MATCH (n:Metadata)
RETURN {
    source_name: "San Francisco Assessor Office",
    date_exported: n.sf_assessor
}`;

export async function assessorSourceQueryHandler(app) {
  const session = app.locals.neo4jDriver.session();
  try {
    const result = await session.run(query, {});
    return (result.records[0] || []).get(0);
  } finally {
    await session.close();
  }
}

export default {
  assessorSourceQueryHandler
};

  } finally {
    await session.close();

}

    await session.close();

server/rest/handlers/query/index.js

// Collects functions that implement the query abstraction layer for ebook api.
//
// Map of query handler functions, to be passed in to the rest listeners via
// app.locals.
// 
// This has the advantage of allowing dependency injection -- a set of mock
// handlers can be passed in instead, for use in a unit test harness.

import { parcelDetailsQueryHandler } from './parcel/details';
import { parcelEvictionsQueryHandler } from './parcel/evictions';
import { parcelPortfolioQueryHandler } from './parcel/portfolio';
import { parcelOwnersQueryHandler } from './parcel/owners';
import { parcelNetworkDetailsQueryHandler } from './parcel/networkDetails';
import { parcelRelatedNetworksQueryHandler } from './parcel/relatedNetworks';
import { ownerDetailsQueryHandler } from './owner/details';
import { ownerEvictionsQueryHandler } from './owner/evictions';
import { ownerPortfolioQueryHandler } from './owner/portfolio';
import { ownerNetworkDetailsQueryHandler } from './owner/networkDetails';
import { ownerRelatedNetworksQueryHandler } from './owner/relatedNetworks';
import { neighborhoodEvictionsQueryHandler } from './neighborhood/evictions';
import { searchQueryHandler } from './search/search';
import { networkGraphQueryHandler }  from './network/graph';
import { networkDetailsQueryHandler }  from './network/details';
import { networkNodesQueryHandler }  from './network/nodes';
import { networkPortfolioQueryHandler }  from './network/portfolio';
import { networkRelatedNetworksQueryHandler }  from './network/relatedNetworks';
import { evictionSourceQueryHandler }  from './about/eviction';
import { assessorSourceQueryHandler }  from './about/assessor';
import { businessSourceQueryHandler }  from './about/business';

const queryHandlers = {
  "networkGraph": networkGraphQueryHandler,
  "networkDetails": networkDetailsQueryHandler,
  "networkPortfolio": networkPortfolioQueryHandler,
  "networkNodes": networkNodesQueryHandler,
  "networkRelatedNetworks": networkRelatedNetworksQueryHandler,
  "parcelDetails": parcelDetailsQueryHandler,
  "parcelEvictions": parcelEvictionsQueryHandler,
  "parcelPortfolio": parcelPortfolioQueryHandler,
  "parcelOwners": parcelOwnersQueryHandler,
  "parcelNetworkDetails": parcelNetworkDetailsQueryHandler,
  "parcelRelatedNetworks": parcelRelatedNetworksQueryHandler,
  "ownerDetails": ownerDetailsQueryHandler,
  "ownerEvictions": ownerEvictionsQueryHandler,
  "ownerPortfolio": ownerPortfolioQueryHandler,
  "ownerNetworkDetails": ownerNetworkDetailsQueryHandler,
  "ownerRelatedNetworks": ownerRelatedNetworksQueryHandler,
  "neighborhoodEvictions": neighborhoodEvictionsQueryHandler,
  "search": searchQueryHandler,
  "evictionSource": evictionSourceQueryHandler,
  "assessorSource": assessorSourceQueryHandler,
  "businessSource": businessSourceQueryHandler
};

export default queryHandlers;

server/rest/handlers/query/neighborhood/evictions.js

// neighborhood.js
//
// query runner backing '/api/neighborhood/' routes.

// string representing cypher query template.
//
// given the name of a neighborhood in san francisco, retrieves detailed
// information about all the evictions from evictorbook datastore which occured
// within that neighborhood's boundaries.

// need to:
//    - only show a single row for each eviction (e.g. if an eviction is matched
//      to multiple addresses, some of which are in the neighborhood, need to 
//      pick just one of the addresses in the neighborhood, and also show
//      how many addresses in total were matched to the eviction).
//    - show the evictor from the sales transfer data, and also create a list 
//      of the other evictors found on the eviction petition
const query = `
  // first look up all evictions associated with properties in the neighborhood
  MATCH (p:A_Parcel)-[r_eviction]-(eviction:RB_Eviction)
  WHERE p.neighborhood = $neighborhood

  // each eviction may be associated with multiple properties. pick one that 
  // is in the neighborhood

  // look up all of the properies associated with each eviction (in the neighborhood)
  // count all parcels and pick one to display
  OPTIONAL MATCH (eviction)-[:EVICTION_AT]-(parc:A_Parcel)
  WHERE parc.neighborhood = $neighborhood
  WITH eviction, CASE WHEN parc IS NULL THEN 0 ELSE COUNT(DISTINCT parc) - 1 END AS num_other_parc, COLLECT(parc)[0] AS display_parc

  // now that we have a single parcel for each eviction, look up the relationship again
  OPTIONAL MATCH (eviction)-[rel_eviction:EVICTION_AT]-(display_parc)

  // identify the evictor from sales transfer data
  OPTIONAL MATCH (evictor:RB_Evictor)-[rel_evictor:EVICTED_BY]-(eviction)
  WHERE rel_evictor.evictor_origin = "SALES_TRANSFER"

  // identify additional evictors associated with eviction petition
  OPTIONAL MATCH (extra_evictor:RB_Evictor)-[rel_extra_evictor:EVICTED_BY]-(eviction)
  WHERE rel_extra_evictor.evictor_origin <> "SALES_TRANSFER"

  WITH display_parc, eviction, num_other_parc, rel_eviction, evictor, CASE WHEN extra_evictor IS NULL THEN [] ELSE COLLECT({
    evictor_name: extra_evictor.evictor,
    source: rel_extra_evictor.evictor_origin
  }) END AS extra_evictors

  OPTIONAL MATCH (evictor)-[:BE_LINKED_TO]-(be_evictor)

  // look up the main address to display 
  OPTIONAL MATCH (display_parc)-[{ source: "ASSESSOR"}]-(assess_addr:Parcel_Address) // first try to look up the parcel address from assessor
  WITH DISTINCT display_parc, eviction, num_other_parc, rel_eviction, evictor, extra_evictors, be_evictor, CASE WHEN NOT assess_addr IS NULL THEN assess_addr.addr ELSE NULL END AS assessor_addr 

  OPTIONAL MATCH (display_parc)-[{ source: "EAS"}]-(alt_addr:Parcel_Address) // look up an alternate address in case there is none
  WITH DISTINCT display_parc, eviction, num_other_parc, rel_eviction, evictor, extra_evictors, be_evictor, assessor_addr, CASE WHEN NOT alt_addr IS NULL THEN COLLECT(alt_addr)[0].addr ELSE NULL END AS alt_addr 

  // use assessor address if present, otherwise alternative address
  WITH DISTINCT display_parc, eviction, num_other_parc, rel_eviction, evictor, extra_evictors, be_evictor, CASE WHEN assessor_addr IS NULL THEN alt_addr ELSE assessor_addr END AS display_addr 

  RETURN {
    evict_id: eviction.evict_id,
    evict_date: eviction.evict_date,
    evict_addr_orig: eviction.addr_orig,
    units: TOFLOAT(display_parc.units),
    type: eviction.type,
    lat: TOFLOAT(display_parc.lat),
    long: TOFLOAT(display_parc.long),
    addr: display_parc.addr,
    block_lot: display_parc.block_lot,
    num_other_parc: num_other_parc,
    primary_evictor: {
      name: evictor.evictor,
      linked_be: CASE WHEN be_evictor IS NULL THEN NULL ELSE {
          __typename: LABELS(be_evictor)[0],
          network_id: be_evictor.network_id
      } END
    },
    extra_evictors: extra_evictors,
    match_quality: {
      did_subdivision_occur: rel_eviction.eviction_type,
      addr_match_method: rel_eviction.addr_match_type
    }
  }
  ORDER BY eviction.evict_date DESC
  SKIP TOINTEGER($skip)
  LIMIT TOINTEGER($size)
`;

// queryHandler callback. implements query for GetEvictionsByNeighborhood.
//  uri: '/api/neighborhood/:neighborhood/evictions',
//       '/api/neighborhood/:neighborhood/evictions/:page'
//
// returns an object with propety 'evictions' set to a list of evictions.
// evictions conform to QueryProto.SFRBEvictionMetadata.
//
// inputs:
//   neighborhood - a string representing the name of a neighborhood in sf,
//     exactly as it appears in the graph datastore.
//   size - integer < 0, the number of results to return.
//   page - integer < 0, described which 'page' of results to return (1 for the
//     first N results, 2 for the second N results, etc., where N is 'size').
export async function neighborhoodEvictionsQueryHandler(
    app, neighborhood, page = 1, size = 100) {
  // validate input params.

  // note: isInteger does an explicit type-check; it does not support
  // string-to-number conversion.
  if (!Number.isInteger(page) || (page <= 0)) {
    throw "neighborhood: bad page, expected integer > 0 got: " +
        page + " with type " + typeof page;
  }
  if (!Number.isInteger(size) || (page <= 0)) {
    throw "neighborhood: bad size, expected integer > 0, got: " +
        size + " with type " + typeof size;
  }
  if (!neighborhood || typeof neighborhood !== "string") {
    throw "neighborhod: bad name, expected string, got type: " +
        typeof neighborhood;
  }

  // query:
  const session = app.locals.neo4jDriver.session();
  try {
    const skip = (page - 1) * size;  // no. of results to skip in query.
    const queryResponse = await session.run(query, { neighborhood, skip, size });

    const responseList = [];
    for (const record_ind in queryResponse.records) {
      const record = queryResponse.records[record_ind];
      responseList.push(record.get(0));
    }
    return responseList;
  } finally {
    await session.close();
  }
}

export default {
  neighborhoodEvictionsQueryHandler
}

server/rest/handlers/query/network/details.js

// network/details.js

const details_query = `
// get total BEs
OPTIONAL MATCH (n:SOS_LP) 
WHERE n.network_id = $network_id
WITH CASE WHEN n IS NULL THEN 0 ELSE COUNT(n) END AS num_lp
OPTIONAL MATCH (n:SOS_Corp) 
WHERE n.network_id = $network_id
WITH CASE WHEN n IS NULL THEN 0 ELSE COUNT(n) END AS num_corp, num_lp
WITH num_corp + num_lp AS total_bes

// get most connected BEs
OPTIONAL MATCH (n:SOS_LP) 
WHERE n.network_id = $network_id
WITH total_bes, CASE WHEN n IS NULL THEN [] ELSE COLLECT(n) END AS be_list
OPTIONAL MATCH (n:SOS_Corp) 
WHERE n.network_id = $network_id
WITH total_bes, CASE WHEN n IS NULL THEN be_list ELSE COLLECT(n) + be_list END AS be_list

UNWIND (CASE be_list WHEN [] THEN [NULL] ELSE be_list END) AS n
WITH total_bes, n, SIZE(()--(n)) AS degree
WITH total_bes, n ORDER BY degree DESC LIMIT 1
WITH total_bes, COLLECT({name_norm: n.name_norm, __typename: LABELS(n)[0]})[0] AS top_be 

// get most connected owners
OPTIONAL MATCH (n:SOS_Owner) 
WHERE n.network_id = $network_id
WITH total_bes, top_be, n, SIZE(()--(n)) AS degree
WITH total_bes, top_be, n ORDER BY degree DESC LIMIT 1
WITH total_bes, top_be, CASE WHEN n IS NULL THEN 0 ELSE COUNT(n) END AS total_owners, COLLECT({name_norm: n.name_norm})[0] AS top_owner 

OPTIONAL MATCH (n:Address_Unit) 
WHERE n.network_id = $network_id
WITH total_bes, top_be, total_owners, top_owner, n, SIZE(()--(n)) AS degree
WITH total_bes, top_be, total_owners, top_owner, n ORDER BY degree DESC LIMIT 1
WITH total_bes, top_be, total_owners, top_owner, CASE WHEN n IS NULL THEN 0 ELSE COUNT(n) END AS total_addrs, COLLECT({addr_readable: n.addr_readable})[0] AS top_addr

RETURN {
  total_bes: total_bes,
  total_addrs: total_addrs,
  total_owners: total_owners,
  top_be: top_be,
  top_owner: top_owner.name_norm,
  top_addr: top_addr.addr_readable
}`;

export async function networkDetailsQueryHandler(app, network_id) {
  const session = app.locals.neo4jDriver.session();
  if (!Number.isInteger(network_id) || (network_id <= 0)) {
    throw "network_id: bad name, expected integer > 0, got type: " +
        typeof network_id;
  }

  try {
    const result = await session.run(details_query, { network_id });
    return result.records[0].get(0);
  } finally {
    await session.close();
  } 
}

export default {
  networkDetailsQueryHandler
}

server/rest/handlers/query/network/graph.js

// network/graph.js

const graph_query = `OPTIONAL MATCH (lp:SOS_LP) // get the LPs in the network
WHERE lp.network_id = $network_id
WITH DISTINCT CASE WHEN lp IS NULL THEN [] ELSE COLLECT(DISTINCT lp) END AS node_list

OPTIONAL MATCH (corp:SOS_Corp) // get the Corps in the network
WHERE corp.network_id = $network_id
WITH DISTINCT CASE WHEN corp IS NULL THEN node_list ELSE COLLECT(DISTINCT corp) + node_list END AS node_list

OPTIONAL MATCH (n:SOS_Owner) // get the owners for the network
WHERE n.network_id = $network_id
WITH DISTINCT CASE WHEN n IS NULL THEN node_list ELSE COLLECT(DISTINCT n) + node_list END AS node_list

OPTIONAL MATCH (n:Address_Unit) // get the units in the network
WHERE n.network_id = $network_id
WITH DISTINCT CASE WHEN n IS NULL THEN node_list ELSE COLLECT(DISTINCT n) + node_list END AS node_list

OPTIONAL MATCH (n:A_Parcel) // get the properties in the network
WHERE n.network_id = $network_id
WITH DISTINCT CASE WHEN n IS NULL THEN node_list ELSE COLLECT(DISTINCT n) + node_list END AS node_list

// Note from maintainer:
//
// startNode(r) and endNode(r) produce the following representation:
//   {
//     properties: [map of values], // key-value properties of the node.
//                                  // NOTE: variable types. vals can be
//                                  // int, boolean, string, float, etc.
//     identity: <integer_id>,  // internal neo4j node id, subject to change.
//     labels: [<typename>],    // ex: "SOS_LP". our nodes have only 1 label.
//   }
// TODO: consider including the key-value properties of the relations
// themselves, in addition to the key-value properties of the nodes they
// connect.
//
// This representation is the basis for the QueryProto.GraphNode message schema
// in type_definitions/proto/query/graph_util.proto . The proto representation
// makes some changes to allow for compatibility; see graph_util.proto for
// details.
//
// (end of note)

OPTIONAL MATCH (n)-[r]-(m)
WHERE n IN node_list AND m IN node_list
WITH CASE WHEN r IS NULL THEN NULL ELSE {start: startNode(r), type: type(r), end: endNode(r)} END AS network_elem
WITH COLLECT(network_elem) AS network_subgraph

RETURN {
    network_subgraph: network_subgraph
}`;

export async function networkGraphQueryHandler(app, network_id) {
  const session = app.locals.neo4jDriver.session();
  if (!Number.isInteger(network_id) || (network_id <= 0)) {
    throw "network_id: bad name, expected integer > 0, got type: " +
        typeof network_id;
  }

  try {
    const result = await session.run(graph_query, { network_id });
    return result.records[0].get(0);
  } finally {
    await session.close();
  } 
}

export default {
  networkGraphQueryHandler
}

server/rest/handlers/query/network/nodes.js

// network/nodes.js
//
// query runner backing '/api/network/:network_id/nodes' routes.

// string representing cypher query template.
//
// given the ID of a network, returns paginated list of entities (i.e. 
// businesses, business owners, and addresses) in the network

const query = `
  WITH $network_id AS network_id

  // look up all the addresses in the network
  OPTIONAL MATCH (address_unit:Address_Unit)
  WHERE address_unit.network_id = network_id

  WITH network_id, CASE WHEN address_unit IS NULL THEN NULL ELSE {
    node: address_unit,
    details: {
      is_business: CASE WHEN EXISTS((address_unit)-[:LISTED_AT]-()) THEN TRUE ELSE FALSE END,
      is_property_owner: CASE WHEN EXISTS((address_unit)--(:A_Parcel)) THEN TRUE ELSE FALSE END
    }
  } END AS node_packaged
  WITH network_id, CASE WHEN node_packaged IS NULL THEN [] ELSE COLLECT(node_packaged) END AS node_list

  // look up all the business owners in the network
  OPTIONAL MATCH (business_owner:SOS_Owner)
  WHERE business_owner.network_id = network_id

  WITH network_id, node_list, CASE WHEN business_owner IS NULL THEN NULL ELSE {
    node: business_owner,
    details: {}
  } END AS node_packaged
  WITH network_id, CASE WHEN node_packaged IS NULL THEN node_list ELSE node_list + COLLECT(node_packaged) END AS node_list

  // look up all the LPs in the network
  OPTIONAL MATCH (business_lp:SOS_LP)
  WHERE business_lp.network_id = network_id

  WITH network_id, node_list, CASE WHEN business_lp IS NULL THEN NULL ELSE {
    node: business_lp,
    details: {}
  } END AS node_packaged
  WITH network_id, CASE WHEN node_packaged IS NULL THEN node_list ELSE node_list + COLLECT(node_packaged) END AS node_list

  // look up all the Corps in the network
  OPTIONAL MATCH (business_corp:SOS_Corp)
  WHERE business_corp.network_id = network_id

  WITH network_id, node_list, CASE WHEN business_corp IS NULL THEN NULL ELSE {
    node: business_corp,
    details: {}
  } END AS node_packaged
  WITH network_id, CASE WHEN node_packaged IS NULL THEN node_list ELSE node_list + COLLECT(node_packaged) END AS node_list

  UNWIND node_list AS node_package

  WITH node_package.node AS node, node_package.details AS details
  WITH node, details, SIZE((node)--()) AS degree // TODO: Limit this to just relationship in the network (i.e. don't include parcel relationships?)
  WITH node, details, degree, LABELS(node)[0] AS node_type 

  RETURN {
    name: CASE WHEN node_type = "Address_Unit" THEN node.addr_readable ELSE node.name_norm END,
    type: node_type,
    degree: degree,
    details: details
  }
  ORDER BY degree DESC
`;

//  uri: '/api/network/:network_id/nodes/:page'
//
// inputs:
//   network_id - ID of the network
//   size - integer < 0, the number of results to return.
//   page - integer > 0, described which 'page' of results to return (1 for the
//     first N results, 2 for the second N results, etc., where N is 'size').
export async function networkNodesQueryHandler(
    app, network_id) {
  // validate input params.

  if (!Number.isInteger(network_id) || (network_id <= 0)) {
    throw "network: bad id, expected integer > 0, got type: " +
        typeof network_id;
  }

  // query:
  const session = app.locals.neo4jDriver.session();
  try {
    const queryResponse = await session.run(query, { network_id });

    const resultContainer = {
      nodes: []
    };
