//  uri: '/api/parcel/:parcel_id/portfolio'
// ========================================
export async function getParcelPortfolio(req, res) {
  try {
    // todo: validate the request.

    // assemble and execute query:
    const search_string = req.params.parcel_id;
    const queryResult = await
      req.app.locals.queryHandlers["parcelPortfolio"](req.app, search_string);

    if (req.app.locals.dbRouteFlags.validate_query_responses &&
          !parcelPortfolioValidatorFn(queryResult)) {
      throw "Query result didn't pass validation!";
    }

    const responseBody = queryResult;

    res.json(responseBody);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('getParcelPortfolio error: ', err);
    res.status(500).send("internal error");
  }
}

    // assemble and execute query:

      req.app.locals.queryHandlers["parcelOwners"](req.app, search_string);

    if (req.app.locals.dbRouteFlags.validate_query_responses &&
          !parcelOwnersValidatorFn(queryResult)) {
      throw "Query result didn't pass validation!";
    }

    res.json(queryResult);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('getParcelOwners error: ', err);
    res.status(500).send("internal error");
  }
}

// =====================================================

  try {
    // todo: validate the request.

    // assemble and execute query:
    const search_string = req.params.parcel_id;

    const queryResult = await req.app.locals.queryHandlers["parcelNetworkDetails"](
      req.app, search_string);

    // if (req.app.locals.dbRouteFlags.validate_query_responses &&
    //       !networkDetailsValidatorFn(queryResult)) {
    //   throw "Query result didn't pass validation!";
    // }

    res.json(queryResult);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('getParcelNetworkDetails error: ', err);
    res.status(500).send("internal error");
  }
};

// ======================================
//  REST listener for GetParcelRelatedNetworks
//  uri: '/api/parcel/:parcel_id/relatedNetworks'
// ======================================
export async function getParcelRelatedNetworks(req, res) {
  try {
    // todo: validate the request.

    // assemble and execute query:
    const search_string = req.params.parcel_id;
    const queryResult = await
      req.app.locals.queryHandlers["parcelRelatedNetworks"](
        req.app, search_string);

    const restructured_data = relatedNetworkPostProcessing(queryResult);

    // confirm queryHandler response fits the expected schema:
    if (req.app.locals.dbRouteFlags.validate_query_responses &&
          !relatedNetworksListValidatorFn(restructured_data)) {
      throw "Query result didn't pass validation!";
    }

    res.json(restructured_data);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('getParcelRelatedNetworks error: ', err);
    res.status(500).send("internal error");
  }
}

// ===============================
//  REST listener for GetOwnerDetails
//  uri: '/api/owner/:business_type/:business_id/details'
// ===============================
export const getOwnerDetails = async function(req, res) {
  try {
    // todo: validate the request.

    // assemble and execute query:
    const search_string = req.params.business_id;
    const be_type = req.params.business_type;

    if (be_type !== "lp"
        && be_type !== "corp") {
      // wrong input_type.
      res.status(400).send(
        'Invalid business entity search type (must be "lp" or "corp")');
      return;
    }

    const queryResult = await
      req.app.locals.queryHandlers["ownerDetails"](
        req.app, be_type, search_string);

    // confirm queryHandler response fits the expected schema:
    if (req.app.locals.dbRouteFlags.validate_query_responses &&
          !ownerDetailsValidatorFn(queryResult)) {
      throw "Query result didn't pass validation!";
    }

    // here, we modify the contents of the result and re-map short string keys
    // to human-readable labels.
    //
    // this is the behavior of the april 2020 preview build.
    //
    // however, this approach has some limitations. for example, it could be
    // useful for the client to have access to both a short code and a
    // human-readable label, and the current api does not allow these.
    //
    // another property of this approach: query abstraction layer and rest
    // layer have fields with identical names but very different semantics.
    // this increases cognitive load for maintainers, and as a result can be
    // considered error-prone.
    //
    // todo: revisit this api. as a potential model for annotated readable
    // labels, see address components in g__maps geocoding api.

    // now, back to the actual post-processing...

    let restructured_data = businessPostProcessing(be_type, queryResult);

    // all done, set result in response body.
    res.json(restructured_data);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('getOwnerDetails error: ', err);
    res.status(500).send("internal error");
  }
};

// ===============================
//  REST listener for GetOwnerEvictions
//  uri: '/api/owner/:business_type/:business_id/evictions'
// ===============================
export const getOwnerEvictions = async function(req, res) {
  try {
    // todo: validate the request.

    // assemble and execute query:
    const search_string = req.params.business_id;
    const be_type = req.params.business_type;

    if (be_type !== "lp"
        && be_type !== "corp") {
      // wrong input_type.
      res.status(400).send(
        'Invalid business entity search type (must be "lp" or "corp")');
      return;
    }

    const queryResult = await
      req.app.locals.queryHandlers["ownerEvictions"](
        req.app, be_type, search_string);

    if (req.app.locals.dbRouteFlags.validate_query_responses &&
          !ownerEvictionsValidatorFn(queryResult)) {
      throw "Query result didn't pass validation!";
    }

    // all done, set result in response body.
    res.json(queryResult);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('getOwnerEvictions error: ', err);
    res.status(500).send("internal error");
  }
};

//  uri: '/api/owner/:business_type/:business_id/portfolio'
// ===============================
export const getOwnerPortfolio = async function(req, res) {

    // todo: validate the request.

    // assemble and execute query:
    const search_string = req.params.business_id;
    const be_type = req.params.business_type;

    if (be_type !== "lp"
        && be_type !== "corp") {
      // wrong input_type.
      res.status(400).send(
        'Invalid business entity search type (must be "lp" or "corp")');
      return;
    }

    const queryResult = await
      req.app.locals.queryHandlers["ownerPortfolio"](
        req.app, be_type, search_string);

    if (req.app.locals.dbRouteFlags.validate_query_responses &&
          !ownerPortfolioValidatorFn(queryResult)) {
      throw "Query result didn't pass validation!";
    }

    // all done, set result in response body.
    res.json(queryResult);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('getOwnerPortfolio error: ', err);
    res.status(500).send("internal error");
  }

    //       !networkDetailsValidatorFn(queryResult)) {

// ===============================
//  REST listener for GetOwnerRelatedNetworks
//  uri: '/api/owner/:business_type/:business_id/relatedNetworks'
// ===============================
export const getOwnerRelatedNetworks = async function(req, res) {
  try {
    // todo: validate the request.

    // assemble and execute query:
    const search_string = req.params.business_id;
    const be_type = req.params.business_type;

    if (be_type !== "lp"
        && be_type !== "corp") {
      // wrong input_type.
      res.status(400).send(
        'Invalid business entity search type (must be "lp" or "corp")');
      return;
    }

    const queryResult = await
      req.app.locals.queryHandlers["ownerRelatedNetworks"](
        req.app, be_type, search_string);

    const restructured_data = relatedNetworkPostProcessing(queryResult);

    if (req.app.locals.dbRouteFlags.validate_query_responses &&
          !relatedNetworkListValidatorFn(restructured_data)) {
      throw "Query result didn't pass validation!";
    }

    // all done, set result in response body.
    res.json(restructured_data);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('getOwnerRelatedNetworks error: ', err);
    res.status(500).send("internal error");
  }
};

// =====================================================
//  REST listener for GetNetworkDetails
//  uri: GET '/api/network/:network_id/details'
// =====================================================
export const getNetworkDetails = async function(req, res) {
  try {
    // assemble and execute query:

    // parse params from strings. do this explicitly here to avoid relying on
    // edge cases for string-to-number conversion later on. Math.floor() does
    // string-to-number conversion and returns integer part.
    //   "" -> 0 -> default, undefined -> NaN -> default, "2.1" -> 2
    const network_id = Math.floor(req.params.network_id);

    const queryResult = await req.app.locals.queryHandlers["networkDetails"](
      req.app, network_id);

    if (req.app.locals.dbRouteFlags.validate_query_responses &&
          !networkDetailsValidatorFn(queryResult)) {
      throw "Query result didn't pass validation!";
    }

    res.json(queryResult);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('getNetworkDetails error: ', err);
    res.status(500).send("internal error");
  }
};

// =====================================================
//  REST listener for GetNetworkNodes
//  uri: GET '/api/network/:network_id/nodes'
// =====================================================
export const getNetworkNodes = async function(req, res) {
  try {
    // assemble and execute query:

    // parse params from strings. do this explicitly here to avoid relying on
    // edge cases for string-to-number conversion later on. Math.floor() does
    // string-to-number conversion and returns integer part.
    //   "" -> 0 -> default, undefined -> NaN -> default, "2.1" -> 2
    const network_id = Math.floor(req.params.network_id);

    const queryResult = await req.app.locals.queryHandlers["networkNodes"](
      req.app, network_id);

    if (req.app.locals.dbRouteFlags.validate_query_responses &&
          !networkNodesValidatorFn(queryResult)) {
      throw "Query result didn't pass validation!";
    }

    const restructured_data = networkNodePostProcessing(queryResult);

    res.json(restructured_data);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('getNetworkNodes error: ', err);
    res.status(500).send("internal error");
  }
};

//  REST listener for GetNetworkRelatedNetworks
//  uri: GET '/api/network/:network_id/relatedNetworks'
// =====================================================
export const getNetworkRelatedNetworks = async function(req, res) {
  try {
    // assemble and execute query:

    // parse params from strings. do this explicitly here to avoid relying on
    // edge cases for string-to-number conversion later on. Math.floor() does
    // string-to-number conversion and returns integer part.
    //   "" -> 0 -> default, undefined -> NaN -> default, "2.1" -> 2
    const network_id = Math.floor(req.params.network_id);

    const queryResult = await req.app.locals.queryHandlers["networkRelatedNetworks"](
      req.app, network_id);

    const restructured_data = relatedNetworkPostProcessing(queryResult);

    if (req.app.locals.dbRouteFlags.validate_query_responses &&
          !relatedNetworkListValidatorFn(restructured_data)) {
      throw "Query result didn't pass validation!";

    res.json(restructured_data);

    res.status(500).send("internal error");

// ===================================================
//  REST listener for GetEvictionsByNeighborhood
//  uri: GET '/api/neighborhood/:neighborhood/evictions',
//       GET '/api/neighborhood/:neighborhood/evictions/:page'
// ===================================================
export const getNeighborhoodEvictions = async function(req, res) {
  try {
    // todo: request validation.

    // assemble and execute query:
    const maxPageSize = req.app.locals.dbRouteFlags.neighborhood_max_page_size;

    const neighborhoodName = req.params.neighborhood.toUpperCase();
    // parse params from strings. do this explicitly here to avoid relying on
    // edge cases for string-to-number conversion later on. Math.floor() does
    // string-to-number conversion and returns integer part.
    //   "" -> 0 -> default, undefined -> NaN -> default, "2.1" -> 2
    const page = Math.floor(req.params.page) || 1;   // caution: 0 -> 1
    const size = Math.floor(req.query.size) || 100;  // caution: 0 -> 100

    // TODO: confirm query params fit the expected schema.

    const queryResult = await
      req.app.locals.queryHandlers["neighborhoodEvictions"](
        req.app, neighborhoodName, page, size);

    // confirm queryHandler response fits the expected schema:
    if (req.app.locals.dbRouteFlags.validate_query_responses &&
      !neighborhoodEvictionsValidatorFn(queryResult)) {
      throw "Query result didn't pass validation!";
    }

    // post-processing:

    // TODO: convert dates, addresses, etc., in 'result' to human-readable
    // format suitable for transmission to client app.
    // see: https://github.com/antievictionmappingproject/evictorbook/issues/205
    res.json(queryResult);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('getNeighborhoodEvictions error: ', err);
    res.status(500).send("internal error");
  }
};

// ===================================
//  REST listener for Search
//  uri: GET '/api/search/:search_term'
// ===================================
export const getSearch = async function(req, res) {
  try {
    const address = req.params.search_term;

    const queryResult = await
      req.app.locals.queryHandlers["search"](req.app, address);

    if (req.app.locals.dbRouteFlags.validate_query_responses &&
          !databaseSearchResultListValidatorFn(queryResult)) {
      throw "Query result didn't pass validation!";
    }

    res.json(queryResult);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('getSearch error: ', err);
    res.status(500).send("internal error");
  }
};

// additional route handlers:

// ========================================================================
//  REST listener for PingRequest (test basic functionality/health check).
//  uri: '/api/ping'
// ========================================================================
export const handlePingRequest = async function(req, res) {
  // nothing useful in request body.
  const result = {
    result: "PONG",
    status: "OK"
  };

  // debugging, remove before merge:
  // update (2021/03/19): starting to like this, might leave it in.
  console.error("ping: dbRouteFlags: ", req.app.locals.dbRouteFlags);

  res.json(result);
}

// ===================================
//  REST listener for a sample test
//  Note: This is boilerplate code to be used to add 
//  test queries, enabled if there is a test Neo4j URI 
//  added to the docker compose flags. 

//  Search for "Adding Test Queries" in the code base to see other 
//  main places code should be added

//  uri: GET '/api/test/sample/:query_param'
// ===================================
export const getTestSample = async function(req, res) {
  try {
    console.log("getTestSample")

    const query_param = req.params.query_param;

    const queryResult = await
      req.app.locals.queryTestHandlers["sample"](req.app, query_param);

    res.json(queryResult);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('getTestSample error: ', err);
    res.status(500).send("internal error");
  }
};

export default {
  getParcelDetails,
  getParcelEvictions,
  getParcelPortfolio,
  getParcelOwners,
  getParcelNetworkDetails,
  getParcelRelatedNetworks,
  getOwnerDetails,
  getOwnerEvictions,
  getOwnerPortfolio,
  getOwnerNetworkDetails,
  getOwnerRelatedNetworks,
  getNetworkDetails,
  getNetworkNodes,
  getNetworkPortfolio,
  getNetworkGraph,
  getNetworkRelatedNetworks,
  getNeighborhoodEvictions,
  getSearch,
  getEvictionSource,
  getAssessorSource,
  getBusinessSource,
  handlePingRequest,
  getTestSample
};

server/rest/routes/dbRoutePostProcessing.js

// dbRoutePostProcessing.js

// contains post-processing functions for returns from Cypher queries,
// for use in dbRouteListeners.js

import { capsToTitleCase } from '../../utils/gnarly/stringUtils';

export const networkNodePostProcessing = function(response) {
    response.nodes = response.nodes.map(node => {
      let renamed_type;
      switch (node.type) {
        case "SOS_LP":
          renamed_type = "Business (Limited Partnership)";
          break;
        case "SOS_Corp":
          renamed_type = "Business (Corporation)";
          break;
        case "Address_Unit":
          if (node.details.is_business && node.details.is_property_owner)
            renamed_type = "Property Owner and Business Office Address";
          else if (node.details.is_property_owner)
            renamed_type = "Property Owner Mailing Address";
          else if (node.details.is_business)
            renamed_type = "Business Office Address";
          else
            renamed_type = "Address";

          break;
        case "SOS_Owner":
          renamed_type = "Business Owner";
          break;
        default:
          renamed_type = node.type
      }
      
      return {
        name: node.name,
        degree: node.degree,
        type: node.type,
        type_readable: renamed_type
      }
    });

    return response
}

export const businessPostProcessing = function(be_type, response) {
    if (be_type !== "lp" && be_type !== "corp") {
      // wrong input_type.
      throw "Invalid business entity search type (must be 'lp' or 'corp')";
    }

    // convert addresses to title case
    response.office_addresses = response.office_addresses.map(addr => 
      capsToTitleCase(addr)
    );

    if (be_type === "lp") {
      response = lpPostProcessing(response);
    } else {
      response = corpPostProcessing(response);
    }

    return response;
}

const corpPostProcessing = function(response) {
      // remap the corporation code
    let status;
    switch(response.be_specific_details.status) {
      case "1":
        status = "Active";
        break;
      case "2":
        status = "Suspended";
        break;
      case "3":
        status = "Canceled";
        break;
      case "4":
        status = "Surrendered";
        break;
      case "5":
        status = "Term expired";
        break;
      case "6":
        status = "Dissolved";
        break;
      case "7":
        status = "Forfeited";
        break;
      case "8":
        status = "Deleted";
        break;
      case "9":
        status = "Inactive";
        break;
      case "C":
        status = "Merged Out";
        break;
      case "E":
        status = "State to Federal Bank Conversion";
        break;
      case "F":
        status = "Conditionally dissolved (No tax clearance)";
        break;
      default:
        status = "Converted Out";
    }
    response.be_specific_details.status = status;

    // remap the corporation type
    let corporation_type;
    switch(response.be_specific_details.corporation_type) {
      case "ARTS":
        corporation_type = "Articles of Incorporation";
        break;
      case "S&DC":
        corporation_type = "Statement & Designation By Foreign Corporation";
        break;
      case "S&DA":
        corporation_type = "Statement & Designation By Foreign Association";
        break;
      case "FNRE":
        corporation_type = "Foreign Name Registration";
        break;
      default:
        corporation_type = "";
    }
    response.be_specific_details.corporation_type = corporation_type;

    // remap the corporation tax base
    let corporation_tax_base;
    switch(response.be_specific_details.corporation_tax_base) {
      case "S":
        corporation_tax_base = "Stock";
        break;
      case "N":
        corporation_tax_base = "Non-Stock (Nonprofit)";
        break;
      default:
        corporation_tax_base = "";
    }
    response.be_specific_details.corporation_tax_base = corporation_tax_base;

    // remap the corporation tax base
    let ftb_suspension_status;
    switch(response.be_specific_details.ftb_suspension_status) {
      case "F":
        ftb_suspension_status = "Forfeited";
        break;
      case "S":
        ftb_suspension_status = "Suspended";
        break;
      default:
        ftb_suspension_status = "Not Suspended (In Good Standing)";
    }
    response.be_specific_details.ftb_suspension_status = ftb_suspension_status;

    // remap the corporation classification
    let corporation_classification;
    switch(response.be_specific_details.corporation_classification) {
      case "AG":
        corporation_classification = "Agricultural Cooperative";
        break;
      case "CR":
        corporation_classification = "Credit Union";
        break;
      case "MU":
        corporation_classification = "Mutual Benefit";
        break;
      case "OC":
        corporation_classification = "Other Cooperative";
        break;
      case "PB":
        corporation_classification = "Public Benefit";
        break;
      case "RE":
        corporation_classification = "Religious";
        break;
      case "SL":
        corporation_classification = "Corporation Sole";
        break;
      case "UN":
        corporation_classification = "Unclassified";
        break;
      default:
        corporation_classification = "";
    }
    response.be_specific_details.corporation_classification =
        corporation_classification;

    return response;
}

export const lpPostProcessing = function(response) {
    let status;
    switch(response.be_specific_details.status) {
      case "A":
        status = "Active";
        break;
      case "B":
        status = "Dishonored Check";
        break;
      case "C":
        status = "Canceled";
        break;
      case "D":
        status = "Dissolved";
        break;
      case "P":
        status = "Pending Cancellation";
        break;
      case "F":
        status = "Franchise Tax Board (FTB) Suspended/Forfeited";
        break;
      case "M":
        status = "Merged Out";
        break;
      case "O":
        status = "Converted Out";
        break;
      case "S":
        status = "Secretary of State (SOS) Suspended/Forfeited";
        break;
      case "2":
        status = "SOS/FTB Suspended/Forfeited";
        break;
      default:
        status = "";
    }
    response.be_specific_details.status = status;

    // remap the filing type
    let filing_type;
    switch(response.be_specific_details.filing_type) {
      case "D":
        filing_type = "Domestic Filing";
        break;
      case "F":
        filing_type = "Foreign Filing";
        break;
      default:
        status = "";
    }
    response.be_specific_details.filing_type = filing_type;

    // remap the management code
    let llc_management_code;
    switch(response.be_specific_details.llc_management_code) {
      case "1":
        llc_management_code = "One Manager";
        break;
      case "M":
        llc_management_code = "More Than One Manager";
        break;
      case "A":
        llc_management_code = "All Members are Managers";
        break;
      default:
        status = "";
    }
    response.be_specific_details.llc_management_code = llc_management_code;

    // LLC type of business comes directly from source data, will be capitalized (if present)
    if (response.be_specific_details.llc_type_of_business) {
      response.be_specific_details.llc_type_of_business = capsToTitleCase(response.be_specific_details.llc_type_of_business);
    }

    return response;
}

/* relatedNetworkPostProcessing: Restructures the data returned
 * for related networks to make for easier processing. Specifically,
 * removes the match explanations from separate fields (which may be null)
 * under the `match_explanation` field and turns them
 * into a single `explanations` array containing the non-null match 
 * explanations.
 */
export const relatedNetworkPostProcessing = function(response) {
    const explanationTypes = ["businesses_listed_at_addrs", 
                              "related_to_excluded",
                              "businesses_owning_parcels", 
                              "parcels_owned_by_same_non_business_owner",
                              "similar_addresses"];

    response = response.map((relatedNetwork) => {
      relatedNetwork.explanations = explanationTypes.map((exp) => (
        {
          exp_type: exp,
          exp_metrics: relatedNetwork.match_explanation[exp]              
        }
      ))

      relatedNetwork.explanations = relatedNetwork.explanations.filter(function (el) {
        return el.exp_metrics != null;
      }); 

      delete relatedNetwork.match_explanation;

      return relatedNetwork;    
    })


    return response;
}

server/rest/routes/dbRouteSetup.js

import memoryCache from 'memory-cache';

import queryHandlers from '../handlers/query';
import queryTestHandlers from '../handlers/queryTest'; // only used if test Neo4j URI is given

import dbRouteListeners from './dbRouteListeners.js';

// TODO - determine how to unify with default (V2 routes)
import unifiedSearch from './unifiedSearch.js';

// Service handler interfaces.
// TODO(Dana): Deprecate and remove.
import unifiedSearchHandler from '../handlers/unifiedSearch/serviceHandler.js';
import queryHandler from '../handlers/query/serviceHandler.js';
import queryTestHandler from '../handlers/queryTest/serviceHandler.js'; // only used if test Neo4j URI is given

import dbRouteFlags from '../../flags/dbRouteFlags.js';
import neo4jBackend from '../../backends/neo4jBackend.js';

// response caching:
const cache = new memoryCache.Cache();

// Returns an express middleware arrow-function which attaches relevant
// response headers and performs the cache lookup/maintainence.
const buildCacheMiddleware = (duration) => {  // duration in minutes
  if (!duration || duration < 0) {
    // Short-circuit, if there's no duration set then return a passthrough fn.
    return (req, res, next) => { next(); };
  }

  // Otherwise, return a fn that stores responses in an in-memory cache.
  return (req, res, next) => {
    const duration_sec = duration * 60;  // to seconds

    // Set header to instruct clients to maintain their own cache, in addition
    // to the serverside one.
    res.set('Cache-Control', `public, max-age=${duration_sec}`);

    const key =  '__eb_api__' + req.originalUrl || req.url;
    const cacheContent = cache.get(key);
    if (cacheContent) {
      res.send(cacheContent);
      console.log('cache hit');
      return;
    }

    // If we're here, cache.get() returned no response body.
    res.sendResponse = res.send;
    res.send = (body) => {
      console.log('cache miss');
      cache.put(key, body, duration_sec * 1000);  // to millis
      res.sendResponse(body);
    }
    next();
  };
};

// amount of time to keep responses in cache, where applicable.
const CACHE_DURATION_MINUTES = 1;

// export routes.
// this is an arrow-function invoked by framework at startup. 'app' parameter
// is the express app object, used to set application state.
export default (app) => {
  app.enable('etag');

  // callback functions to implement query abstraction layer.
  app.locals.queryHandlers = queryHandlers;
  app.locals.queryTestHandlers = queryTestHandlers;

  // flags to control db route behavior.
  app.locals.dbRouteFlags = dbRouteFlags;

  // configure the neo4j database backends.
  app.locals.neo4jDriver = neo4jBackend({ use_test_endpoint: false });

  // if specified in docker flags, create another Neo4j driver pointing 
  // to the remote, testing db. Also enables a set of test API routes 
  // that query this DB. 
  if (dbRouteFlags.enable_test) {
    app.locals.neo4jDriverTest = neo4jBackend({ use_test_endpoint: true });
  }

  // local service handlers.
  //
  // work-in-progress / proof-of-concept: treat v1 queries as a service. if
  // this works, then we can remove the ad-hoc queryHandler construct.
  if (!app.locals.services) {
    app.locals.services = {};
  }
  app.locals.services.unifiedSearchHandler = unifiedSearchHandler;
  app.locals.services.queryHandler = queryHandler;
  app.locals.services.queryTestHandler = queryTestHandler;

  let cacheFn;
  if (dbRouteFlags.disable_cache) {
    // Short-circuit, if cache is disabled then use a passthrough fn:
    cacheFn = (req, res, next) => { next(); };
  } else {
    cacheFn = buildCacheMiddleware(CACHE_DURATION_MINUTES);
  }

  // TODO - review these and see which should stay in

  // // route for health-check / basic functionality testing.
  // app.get('/api/ping', dbRouteListeners.handlePingRequest);

  // // routes for index-based searches.
  // app.get('/api/be-search/:search', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.searchBENames);
  // app.get('/api/parcel-search/:search', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.searchParcelNames);

  if (dbRouteFlags.enable_unified_search) {
    // route for unified search api.
    // send query string with 'q' query param: '/api/search?q=foo'
    app.get('/api/search', cacheFn, unifiedSearch.unifiedSearchListener);
  }

  // ROUTES FOR INDEX-BASED SEARCHES
  //    search_term: search term to use when looking up owners (business name)
  //                 and parcels (street address)
  // app.get('/api/search/:search_term', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getSearch);

  // ROUTES FOR NEIGHBORHOOD VIEW
  app.get('/api/neighborhood/:neighborhood/evictions', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getNeighborhoodEvictions);
  app.get('/api/neighborhood/:neighborhood/evictions/:page', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getNeighborhoodEvictions);

  // ROUTES FOR OWNER VIEW
  //    business_id: currently the 'name_norm' field for both LPs and Corps (e.g. "55 DOLORES STREET LLC")
  //    business_type: can be either 'lp' or 'corp'
  //
  // details about the searched business:
  app.get('/api/owner/:business_type/:business_id/details', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getOwnerDetails);
  // evictions conducted by the searched business:
  app.get('/api/owner/:business_type/:business_id/evictions', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getOwnerEvictions);
  // portfolio of properties owned by business network:
  app.get('/api/owner/:business_type/:business_id/portfolio', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getOwnerPortfolio);
  // details of network containing business:
  app.get('/api/owner/:business_type/:business_id/networkDetails', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getOwnerNetworkDetails);
  // potential networks related to business network:
  app.get('/api/owner/:business_type/:business_id/relatedNetworks', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getOwnerRelatedNetworks);

  // ROUTES FOR NETWORK VIEW
  //    network_id: unique, numerical identifier for ownership network
  //
  app.get('/api/network/:network_id/details', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getNetworkDetails);
  app.get('/api/network/:network_id/portfolio', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getNetworkPortfolio);
  app.get('/api/network/:network_id/nodes', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getNetworkNodes);
  app.get('/api/network/:network_id/graph', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getNetworkGraph);
  // NOTE: this is equivalent to the returns from the parcel / owner routes:
  app.get('/api/network/:network_id/relatedNetworks', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getNetworkRelatedNetworks);

  // ROUTES FOR PARCEL VIEW
  //    parcel_id: currently the 'block_lot' field (e.g. "3502033")
  //
  // details about the searched property:
  app.get('/api/parcel/:parcel_id/details', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getParcelDetails);
  // evictions at the searched property:
  app.get('/api/parcel/:parcel_id/evictions', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getParcelEvictions);
  // portfolio of properties that the searched property is part of:
  app.get('/api/parcel/:parcel_id/portfolio', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getParcelPortfolio);
  // property owners for searched property:
  app.get('/api/parcel/:parcel_id/owners', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getParcelOwners);
  // details of network containing parcel:
  app.get('/api/parcel/:parcel_id/networkDetails', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getParcelNetworkDetails);
  // potential networks related to the property:
  app.get('/api/parcel/:parcel_id/relatedNetworks', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getParcelRelatedNetworks);

  // ROUTES FOR DATA SOURCE DETAILS
  // NOTE: This is not a comprehensive list of data sources
  //
  // get details on the City eviction data source
  app.get('/api/about/eviction', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getEvictionSource);
  // get details on the County property ownership / assessor data source
  app.get('/api/about/assessor', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getAssessorSource);
  // get details on the State business data source
  app.get('/api/about/business', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getBusinessSource);

  // route for health-check / basic functionality testing.
  app.get('/api/ping', dbRouteListeners.handlePingRequest);

  if (dbRouteFlags.enable_test) {
    // add test queries here (search for "Adding Test Queries" in the code base to see other main places
    // code should be added)

    // placeholder sample test query, returns nothing
    app.get('/api/test/sample/:query_param', cacheFn, dbRouteListeners.getTestSample);
  }

}

server/rest/routes/sessionRoutes.js

export default (app, loginLimiter) => {
  //constants
  const USERNAME = process.env.UI_USERNAME;
  const PASSWORD = process.env.UI_PASSWORD;
  const TEMP_PASSWORD = process.env.UI_TEMP_PASSWORD;

  const isUser = (username, password) => {
    return username === USERNAME &&
      ( password === PASSWORD || password === TEMP_PASSWORD )
  }

  const sessionChecker = (req, res) => {
    const { user } = req.session;
    if ( user !== undefined && isUser(user.username, user.password) ) {
      res.send(JSON.stringify({ response: true, newUser: user }));
    } else {
      console.error("Session checker false.");
      // NOTE: change back, res.send(JSON.stringify({ response: false }));
      //this can be toggled to turn off the login
      res.send(JSON.stringify({ response: false, newUser: user }));
    }
  };

  // route logic for login
  app
    .route("/session/login")
    .get(sessionChecker, (req, res) => {
      console.log("session checker finished");
    })
    .post(loginLimiter, (req, res) => {
      const { username, password } = req.body;

      if ( isUser(username, password) ) {
        const newUser = {
          username,
          password,
        };

        //add user object to session
        req.session.user = newUser;
        res.send(
          JSON.stringify({
            response: true,
            newUser,
            rateLimit: req.rateLimit, //this can be used in the client
          })
        );
      } else {
        res.send(
          JSON.stringify({
            response: false,
            newUser: null,
            rateLimit: req.rateLimit, //this can be used in the client
          })
        );
      }
    });

  //route logic for logout
  app.get("/session/logout", (req, res) => {
    //destroy the sesssion
    req.session = null;
    res.send(JSON.stringify({ message: "Session ended." }));
  });
};

server/rest/routes/unifiedSearch.js

// unifiedSearch.js
//
// Contains request listener for the unified search REST endpoint. Handles the
// business logic only, not the route configuration/setup. see
// type_definitions/proto/search/search.proto for a description of the request
// and response schemas.

// libraries and utilities included from source:
import { checkProto } from '../../framework/protoUtils';
import { capsToTitleCase } from '../../utils/gnarly/stringUtils';
import serviceUtils from '../../framework/serviceUtils';
import statusUtils from '../../framework/statusUtils';

// EbookSearchService:

// ==================================================================
//  REST listener for Search (unified search call).
//  uri: GET '/api/search?q=<query>'
// =================================================================
export async function unifiedSearchListener(req, res) {
  try {
    const app = req.app;

    // extract search string from the uri query params.
    const queryString = req.query.q;
    const databaseVersionTag = req.query.db_version;

    // request validation:
    if (!queryString) {
      // can't find anything if no query is provided.
      res.status(400);
      res.json({
        error: { status: statusUtils.badRequestStatus("bad request; unparseable query string") }
      });
      return;
    }

    const request_data = {};  // search.SearchRequest proto schema.
    request_data.query_string = queryString;
    if (databaseVersionTag) {
      request_data.database_version = databaseVersionTag;
    }
    
    const responseOrError = await app.locals.services.unifiedSearchHandler.invoke(
        app, "Search", request_data);
    
    // Since we have no additional post-processing, we can return the result
    // directly. If the service call was correctly-formed but returned an
    // error, then the function call 'serviceUtils.isResultOk(responseOrError)'
    // would return false.

    res.json(responseOrError);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error('Search error: ', err);
    // TODO: Put this in a utility function.
    res.status(500);
    res.json({
      error: { status: statusUtils.internalErrorStatus() }
    });
  }
}

export default {
  unifiedSearchListener
};

server/rest/server/rest.js

import bodyParser from "body-parser";
import cookieSession from "cookie-session";
import helmet from "helmet";
import express from "express";
import cors from "cors";
import dbRouteSetup from "../routes/dbRouteSetup";
import sessionRoutes from "../routes/sessionRoutes";
import { IpFilter as ipfilter } from "express-ipfilter";
import rateLimit from "express-rate-limit";

export default (app, cookieKey, port) => {
  app.set("trust proxy", 1); // trust first proxy

  // cookie management.
  // track the logged-in user across sessions
  const expiryDate = new Date(Date.now() + 60 * 60 * 96000); // 4 days

  app.use(
    cookieSession({
      name: "session",
      keys: [cookieKey],
      expires: expiryDate
      // TODO: !!! NOTE: THESE WILL NEED TO BE UPDATED FOR PRODUCTION !!!
      // secure: true,
      // httpOnly: true,
      // domain: 'example.com',
      // path: '/login',
      // expires: expiryDate
    })
  );

  // security config:
  app.use(helmet());
  app.disable("x-powered-by");

  // cors
  app.use(cors());

  // for parsing restApplication/json:
  app.use(bodyParser.json());

  // for parsing restApplication/x-www-form-urlencoded:
  app.use(express.urlencoded({ extended: true }));

  // TODO  The whitelist will need to be updated for production
  // ipfilter. whitelist IPs
  // const ips = ["127.0.0.1", "::ffff:127.0.0.1"];
  // app.use(ipfilter(ips, { mode: 'allow' }));

  // set default rate limiting config, for rest api:
  const apiLimiter = rateLimit({
    windowMs: 5 * 60 * 1000, // 5 minutes
    max: 1000,
    skipSuccessfulRequests: false
  });
  app.use('/api/', apiLimiter);

  // rate limiting for login
  const loginLimiter = rateLimit({
    windowMs: 60 * 60 * 1000, // 1 hour window
    max: 50, // start blocking after 50 requests
    skipSuccessfulRequests: true,
    message: "Too many logins, please try again after an hour."
  });

  // set up rest routes.
  dbRouteSetup(app);

  // set up login/session routes. use loginLimiter instead of apiLimiter.
  sessionRoutes(app, loginLimiter);

  // start listening, on the specified port
  app.listen(port, () => {
    console.log(`REST API server ready at http://localhost:${port}`);
  });
};

server/schemas/README.md

Json-Schema Templates

This directory contains json-schema definitions for use in the node server. The intent is to allow for a definition language that's legible and editable for all developers on the evictorbook project.

json-schema has two core advantages over a separate schema-definition language like protocol buffers. First, it's designed to have one-to-one compatibility with everything that can be expressed in json (in contrast to the protocol buffers schema language, which has some unfortunate edge-cases in json intercompatibility). Second, the definitions are represented in the specification as json descriptions, so it doesn't require any additions to the toolchain other than a validation library. We've opted for Ajv, the most widely-supported json-schema validator in the javascript language.

Problems with json-schema: There is a proliferation of draft specifications, and many features are not widely supported across validation libraries. The json format does not natively support inline comments, so it's very difficult to write effective annotations for schema definitions. Most damagingly, schema definitions are difficult to re-use: while the specification offers some support for schema re-use across files, the syntax is cumbersome and error-prone, and not uniformly supported.

To work around these challenges, we've opted to specify our json-schema definitions in the form of .js files. Each .js file is a commonjs module that exports a single object literal which represents a json-schema.

This means we can easily write in-line comments, and we can take advantage of javscript's built-in mechanisms for cross-file inclusion. Individual object schemas are defined in their own .js files so they can be re-used. To include a nested schema, simply call `require(<"filename">)` inline.

Avoid using `definitions` and `$ref` in the json-schema literals; these won't translate well when included in other files. Instead, rely on `require` as described above.

These schema definitions can be directly used in Node with either `require` or `import` syntax.

To resolve one of these schemas and all its imports to json (for example, to use in a json-schema validator in another language), run the following from the command line:

`node compile2json.js <filename> > outfile.json`

Note that you'll lose the inline js comments and any manual formatting from the original definitions.

server/schemas/compile2json.js

// Reads a filename from the command line, interprets it as a module which
// exports a json-compatible object, and writes it as pretty-printed json to
// standard out.
//
// Used to "compile" .js object definitions to json. See README.md
const fs = require("fs");

const filename = process.argv[2];
const resolved = require(filename);

// The additional parameters cause the json string to be pretty-printed with an
// indent of 2 spaces. Remove them for a more compact single-line json.
console.log(JSON.stringify(resolved, null, 2));

server/schemas/compile_all_schemas.sh

# compile_all_schemas.sh
#
# Convenience script to convert all the '.js' schemas into json with
# dependencies resolved. Good for testing whether the schemas result in valid
# javascript objects.
#
# You almost certainly don't want to commit the resulting json files to github
# (because it would be annoying to track whether this script has been run), so
# you can use delete_all_json.sh afterwards to clean up all json files in
# the schema directory.
#
# NOTE: This script attempts to delete the existing json files before
# recompiling, so you'll see extraneous 'file does not exist' errors during that
# step on your first run. These are safe to ignore.

# make sure we're working from the directory of the script, not the caller's
# working directory.
#
# found on stack overflow, tested on linux mint 19. if you find compatibilty
# issues with your platform, please uploaded fixes or workarounds here. thanks!
DIR="$( cd "$( dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}" )" &> /dev/null && pwd)"

pushd $DIR
for filename in $(find ./src -name "*.js"); do outfile="$filename""on"; rm $outfile ; node ./compile2json.js $filename > $outfile ; done
echo "done. if you see any errors other than 'rm: cannot remove <filename>: No such file or directory', then the js schemas did not evaluate to valid json objects."
popd

server/schemas/delete_all_json.sh

#!/bin/bash
#
# delete_all_json.sh
#
# Deletes all .json files in the schema directory. Use this after 'compile_all_schemas.sh' to clean your workspace after a successful compilation. 


# make sure we're working from the directory of the script, not the caller's
# working directory.
#
# found on stack overflow, tested on linux mint 19. if you find compatibilty
# issues with your platform, please uploaded fixes or workarounds here. thanks!
DIR="$( cd "$( dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}" )" &> /dev/null && pwd)"

echo Removing .json files from $DIR

for filename in $(find $DIR/src -name "*.json"); do rm $filename ; done

echo "done"

server/schemas/legacy/HOWTO_Compile_protos.md

HOWTO Compile protos

To compile the protos in this directory and generate static code for python and
js, run the following script:

  ./compile_protos.sh

You will need to install `protoc` as well as `pbf`. See details below.

Compile protos to python generated code:
- Install protoc (see below).
- `protoc --python_out=<path_to_output>/python *.proto`
- protoc generates one output file for each input file in the command line invocation.

Compile protos to pbf js code:
- Install mapbox pbf (see below).
- `pbf in.proto > out.js`
- Note: in.proto should 'import' all the other proto files you need for the module. mapbox pbf's compiler merges all dependencies into a single module.
- Note: mapbox pbf uses node's built-in proto schema resolver rather than google's (presumably for licensing reasons). this leads to inconsistent behavior regarding imports and package names, so we're keeping the directory structure simple. 

Installing protoc (the original proto compiler):
- Ubuntu and debian-based distros: sudo apt install protobuf-compiler
- Mac: brew install protobuf
- Other distros: see https://google.github.io/proto-lens/installing-protoc.html for example commands to download and install precompiled binaries
- If you're feeling spicy: clone https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf and compile from source. 

Installing mapbox pbf:
- With nodejs and npm installed, run: npm install -g pbf

server/schemas/legacy/README.md

Type definitions for the evictorbook project.

Consider this the canonical source for schemas on datastores, csv's, http/rest messages in transit, json-based config messages, and anything else that's a clean interface boundary that lends itself to type-checking.

Definitions are written in proto, aka the protocol buffers type definition language. See readme file in ./proto/ subdirectory for details on this format.

Index:
- ./proto - the type definitions themselves. descriptions of file and message schemas used in the ebook codebase, with per-field comments.
- ./gen - autogenerated code to use those type definitions in js, py.

server/schemas/legacy/compile_protos.sh

#!/bin/bash
#
# compile_protos.sh

# Quick and dirty script to compile protos, writing python generated code and
# mapbox pbf modules for js.
#
# DEPRECATED as of 2021/06/14. This should be considered legacy code, and is
# included here on the off-chance that someone will need to generate
# protocol-buffer encoder code from these schemas for external use.
#
# This script is not very robust (doesn't handle error-checking, etc). If you
# run it, you'll notice that it needs the output directories to be created
# ahead of time.



# make sure we're working from the directory of the script, not the caller's
# working directory.
#
# found on stack overflow, tested on linux mint 19. if you find compatibilty
# issues with your platform, please uploaded fixes or workarounds here. thanks!
DIR="$( cd "$( dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}" )" &> /dev/null && pwd)"
echo $DIR

# compile proto packages:

# NOTE: Mapbox pbf compiler cli uses node's bespoke protocol buffer compiler,
# which generates rather terse error messages. Therefore, we use the official
# 'protoc' compiler to build python modules in parallel, to get reasonable
# error message when things go wrong.

# 1. graph protos
pushd $DIR/proto/graph
# clear existing generated code:
rm ../../gen/python/graph/*
rm ../../gen/js/graph/*
# generate python code with protoc:
protoc --python_out=../../gen/python/graph *.proto
# generate js pbf module:
pbf graph.proto > ../../gen/js/graph/index.js
popd

# 2. query abstraction layer protos
pushd $DIR/proto/query
# clear existing generated code:
rm ../../gen/python/query/*
rm ../../gen/js/query/*
# generate python code with protoc:
protoc --python_out=../../gen/python/query *.proto
# generate js pbf module:
pbf query.proto > ../../gen/js/query/index.js
popd

# 3. rest api protos
pushd $DIR/proto/rest
# clear existing generated code:
rm ../../gen/python/rest/*
rm ../../gen/js/rest/*
# generate python code with protoc:
protoc --python_out=../../gen/python/rest *.proto
# generate js pbf modules:
pbf rest.proto > ../../gen/js/rest/index.js
popd

# 4. unified search protos
pushd $DIR/proto/search
# clear existing generated code:
rm ../../gen/python/search/*
rm ../../gen/js/search/*
# generate python code with protoc:
protoc --python_out=../../gen/python/search *.proto
# generate js pbf modules:
pbf search.proto > ../../gen/js/search/index.js
popd

echo "done compiling."


# final step -- copy the generated js into server/ so it can be read by the node container.
#
# TODO: find a more elegant solution here. one option is to move the proto/
# directory under server/, but this has issues for sharing the protos among
# multiple applications.

# NOTE(2021/06/14): Removing this step as the proto definitions have been moved
# under the server/ directory, so there's no need to copy. It's unlikely that
# we'll need to programatically copy these, as we're sunsetting the use of
# protocol buffers for general schema definitions in ebook.

#pushd $DIR
#cp -r ./gen/js/* ../server/gen-proto/
#popd

# TODO: add actual error handling.
# echo "copied generated code."
echo " if you've made it this far and you don't see an error message above, you're done and everything's ok."

# done.

server/schemas/legacy/md-generated/README.md

# Generated Markdown doc

Consider this the "user-friendly" version of the schema documentation. __NOTE that it contains detailed information about the research methodology so it should only be shared with trusted partners!__

* __graph/docs.md__: complete schema description of the evictorbook 1.0 serving graph, which provides the serving data from the initial evictorbook release on may 1, 2020 through present.
* __rest/docs.md__: complete description of evictorbook 1.0 rest api. endpoints, uris, parameters, response json schemas, etc.
* __query/docs.md__: complete description of internal evictorbook query-abstraction-layer, which is the interface boundary between server-side javascript (server/rest/routes/) and runtime cypher queries (server/rest/handlers/). a reference guide for server-side devs, and the basis for server-side unit tests.

Auto-generated from ../proto using https://github.com/pseudomuto/protoc-gen-doc, with necessary hand-edits to fix things that were confusing or straight-up broken in the generator's output. In the future, we'll streamline the proto-to-markdown process so hand-edits are necessary, but until then, expect the Markdown to be updated less frequently.

Word to the wise: if you're a developer and looking for the canonical, up-to-date documentation that can be directly used in code, see the .proto files themselves in ../proto. Those files are intended to be read by both developers and compilers. However, if you are unfamiliar with the .proto language and are seeking an overview of the ebook schema contents, this is the place.

(end note on the generator: before I forget, there's another issue: protoc-gen-doc requires 'go' to work, and it uses a docker container as a compatibility layer. which gets really annoying/confusing when we try to mix if with our docker setup. for that reason, i don't want to make the md generator a critical part of the dev toolchain. -Dana)

server/schemas/legacy/md-generated/graph/docs.md

# Evictorbook Graph Schema Definition 
<a name="top"></a>

### Note for readers

The documentation featured below was originally written in a format called 'proto', and then converted to Markdown. proto is a schema definition language that's intended to be both machine-readable and developer-readable. The motivation is to declare the machine-readable schema directly alongside human-readable comments, in the same file, so the canonical documentation always matches the schema enforced in code. The disadvantage is that .proto syntax requires some getting used to.

In order to produce a more user-friendly and widely readable documentation, we use an automated tool to convert the 'proto' files into Markdown. The text descriptions here are imported directly from the comments in the 'proto' files. This introduces some quirks in formatting (for example, multi-line comments are compressed into a single line in order to fit into the Markdown tables below). Let us know how we did; the Markdown formatting is a work in progress, so let us know if you have suggestions to improve this formatting or make it more readable.

That's the disclaimer. Read on for the documentation.

## Table of Contents

- [graph.proto](#graph.proto)
    - [Graph](#graph.Graph)

    - [Graph.RelationCollection](#graph.Graph.RelationCollection)

    - [CalSOSOwnerData](#graph.CalSOSOwnerData)
    - [NodeDetails](#graph.NodeDetails)
    - [SFAssessorParcelData](#graph.SFAssessorParcelData)
    - [SFAssessorParcelOwnerData](#graph.SFAssessorParcelOwnerData)
    - [SFRentBoardEvictionData](#graph.SFRentBoardEvictionData)
    - [SFRentBoardEvictorData](#graph.SFRentBoardEvictorData)

    - [EvictionAtRelationData](#graph.EvictionAtRelationData)
    - [ListedAtRelationData](#graph.ListedAtRelationData)
