| <a name="sfixed32" /> sfixed32 | Always four bytes. | int32 | int | int | int32 | int | integer | Bignum or Fixnum (as required) |
| <a name="sfixed64" /> sfixed64 | Always eight bytes. | int64 | long | int/long | int64 | long | integer/string | Bignum |
| <a name="bool" /> bool |  | bool | boolean | boolean | bool | bool | boolean | TrueClass/FalseClass |
| <a name="string" /> string | A string must always contain UTF-8 encoded or 7-bit ASCII text. | string | String | str/unicode | string | string | string | String (UTF-8) |
| <a name="bytes" /> bytes | May contain any arbitrary sequence of bytes. | string | ByteString | str | []byte | ByteString | string | String (ASCII-8BIT) |

server/schemas/legacy/proto/README.md

# Type definitions in the proto language.

## What on earth is 'proto'?

TLDR: 'protocol buffers' is a cross-platform, language-agnostic library for defining reusable schemas. 'proto' is the language used to write those schema defitions.

'protocol buffers' consists of:
  1. A non-Turing-complete, self-describing "data defintion language" called 'proto'
  2. A convenient, flexible, well-supported, platform-agnostic library called 'protobuf', widely available in many programming languages, which allow us to use those data definitions. (If that library doesn't fit your requirements, there are a wide range of supplemental proto libraries as generally available open source software.)
  3. A built-in compact data serialization format, fully integrated into the library, which you can use if you find it convenient. If the compact format doesn't fit your requirements, you can instead serialize to json or csv, or any other format -- all you need is an adapter.

## Why is this approach good? (the model.)

The reason this is good is simple: it preserves the best part of programming with sql-based databases. (While it's a simple idea, it is a bit of a long walk, so bear with me...).

In traditional SQL databases systems, the schema is written in a less-expressive, non-Turing-complete "schema definition language" rather than the full "programming language" or "query language". This prompts developers to take special steps when interacting across boundaries, as when the "database client" requests information from the "database server".

Developers treat the client-server boundary like an airlock. The "client" and "server" speak to one another through short code fragments (written in a full Turing-complete "query language"), which are rigorously tested against the agreed-upon schema definitions.

As a helpful side effect, the developer is encouraged to write self-contained modules which interact cleanly with one another. In the case of a traditional SQL database, those modules are all loosely integrated together by their common reliance on the database schema. In other words, a traditional type-safe database schema "tricks us" into writing maintainable, modular code.

Contrast this approach with other ways of processing information. In some high-level programming languages (such as C++ and Java), developers are encouraged to tightly couple their code defintions with their type definitions. That tight coupling tends to introduce unintended complications when decomposing software across multiple processes or services. (And unfortunately for us, decomposing software across multipe processes or servers is _exactly_ what we need to do in distributed systems development.) Those complications tend towards code which is difficult to test and maintain.

## Bringing it back... (applying this approach to proto.)

You may be asking, what does this description of SQL have to do with proto? Well, surprisingly, a lot. Read on:

The whole gimmick with protocol buffers is, we get access to a generic "data definition language" gives us the exact same advantage, as SQL schemas. But, this generic definition language *is free from the constraints of any specific datastore*. the 'proto' language is non-Turing-complete, just like SQL's 'schema defintion langage' subset, which means  the proto language can only express _the composition_ of a data artifact; it can't express the _algorithms_ that manipulate those artifacts.

There's an additional detail, and it's absolutely crucial to proto's success: it can describe tree-like, complex data structures; it's not limited to tabular formats. This solves the so-called "impedence mismatch problem" which has plagued SQL database systems for 30+ years. (For a description of the "impedence mismatch problem", see database expert Martin Fowler's talk from GOTO 2012 (relevant excerpt linked here: https://youtu.be/qI_g07C_Q5I?t=109 .)

Proto definitions have been used in a wide variety of domains to document the interface boundaries that exist in software systems, and have flourished in the open-source ecosystem since 2012-2015. Here are some examples:
  - Alternative to XML for large static data dumps, particularly in map data:
    - Documentation for usage in OpenStreetMap: https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/PBF_Format
  - Real-time serving and rendering of map data:
    - example definition: https://github.com/mapbox/vector-tile-spec/blob/master/2.1/vector_tile.proto
  - Message passing for real-time distributed systems:
    - Moby (docker upstream) networking protocol, definition: https://github.com/moby/libnetwork/blob/d0951081b35fa4216fc4f0064bf065beeb55a74b/networkdb/networkdb.proto
    - usage: https://github.com/moby/libnetwork/blob/d0951081b35fa4216fc4f0064bf065beeb55a74b/networkdb/delegate.go
  - Large-scale data storage in machine learning / parallel data processing frameworks:
    - canonical storage format for TensorFlow: https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/2687479a7cebb4dda26a83f022fb818387b10bfe/tensorflow/core/example/example.proto
    - usage in python: https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/6bb7f19c3d2c11c39da951f388f9112e0649ecfc/tensorflow/python/keras/feature_column/sequence_feature_column_integration_test.py
  - Interface specifications for next-generation Apple machine learning models
    - example definition, see the whole directory: https://github.com/apple/coremltools/blob/master/mlmodel/format/NearestNeighbors.proto
  - Descriptions of REST/JSON request and response payloads (TODO find open-source examples).
  - Database schemas for the persistent storage layer (TODO find open-source examples).
  - Documentation of csv columns for batch jobs (TODO find open-source examples).

If we define a set of semantic type-safe schemas for these all of these formats in a single common interface language, we can get that same "SQL bonus". We get to  "trick ourselves" into writing testable and modular code, throughout our distributed system, no matter what language it's in. And since the proto language is platform-agnostic, and programming-language-agnostic, we get a clean and testable way to mix and match components written in different languages, for free.

This lets is write code that is easily extensible and scalable, without altering our fundamental workflow.

## Benefits for documentation

There's another hidden bonus to using proto, and it's related to documentation:

With the benefit of some clear comments and good documentation practices, the schema-definition folder of your codebase can become the central go-to for canonical documentation about the entire distributed system. The goal is to make one place for the source-of-truth, and to make that source-of-truth accessible to both humans and computer programs.

You may be surprised to learn, in fact, that many large-profile production services generate their API documentation from a .proto definition file. This is how the accompanying Markdown version of this documentation was generated.

## Further reading

- Proto language documentation: https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/overview
  - The official doc, canonical reference for the proto definition language itself, and example usage code highlighting C++, Java, Python, and Go. (javascript, as established, is a second-class citizen in the proto world; see below.)
 
- Thrift whitepaper (aka april fools whitepaper): https://thrift.apache.org/static/files/thrift-20070401.pdf
  - This eight-pager from 2007 is the best publicly available introduction to this style of distributed systems development. Context: 'thrift' is a copycat-reimplementation of proto, made my a corporate rival. The whitepaper is a rare window into the internal machinations of proprietary software development. Key sentence, regarding the use of multiple programming languages interacting seamlessly in a distributed system: "Thrift has allowed the search team to leverage each language for its strengths and to develop code at a rapid pace."

- Sawzall paper: https://static.googleusercontent.com/media/research.google.com/en//archive/sawzall-sciprog.pdf 
  - Contains the original publicly available description of 'protocol buffers', circa 2005. While it ostensibly describes a query language known as 'sawzall' (since deprecated), the real value of this paper is the incidental description of 'proto' woven throughout. See pp. 6-7, 9-10, 19-20, 23. (add back the double '/' after 'en' if the link doesn't work.)

- Library documentation for third-party javscript implementations:
  - protobufjs: https://github.com/protobufjs/protobuf.js
    - Primary use case: integration with C++ proto implementation and extension of C++ proto development patterns into javascript.
  - pbf: https://github.com/mapbox/pbf
    - Primary use case: lightweight, pure js proto compiler and serializer. bare-bones; the open-source version is just the core functionality, and we've written utility functions to incorporate it into our existing js code.
      - example usage (schema definition): https://github.com/mapbox/vector-tile-spec/blob/master/2.1/vector_tile.proto
      - example usage (wrapper library): https://github.com/mapbox/vt-pbf/blob/086d4beed533d944075196872d8c11ef76f7870a/lib/geojson_wrapper.js
      - example usage (actual code): https://github.com/mapbox/vt-pbf/blob/086d4beed533d944075196872d8c11ef76f7870a/index.js

## If you're interested: proto language history, and motivation for technology choice.

Now for some background on the technology choices: the 'protocol buffers' language and library were designed and implemented at 'A Large Search Company' in 2001. It was never intended to be widely available in open-source, and for many years it was considered to be closely-held proprietary technology. However, in an unexpected twist, 'A Large Search Company' was outflanked by a corporate rival, and was strategically forced to open-source the proto language and the protocol buffers library on 07/07/2008 (If you take a moment to reflect on the particular significance of july 2008 in world economic history, you might conclude that this a date where you'd only anounce something if you were 'feeling lucky'.)

The public release of 'protocol buffers' was quickly followed by the corporate rival's re-implementation, 'thrift', which became widely available just in time for christmas in 2009.

The two libraries are very similar in concept, and if you've used one, you can quickly acclimate to the other. However, the reason you should use 'protocol buffers' instead of 'thrift' is that 'protocol buffers' is much more efficiently engineered. 'proto' is the one that had to work in order support the unprecedented operational requirements of 'A Large Search Company Web Search' in 2001-04. in contrast, 'thrift' only had to work well enough to kind-of-scale-up a prominent social networking website. I have used both libraries and can assure you, you will notice the difference.

Important note: one factor which has traditionally held 'protocol buffers' back from widespread adoption outside of proprietary code ecosystems is the lack of first-class javascript support. (This is ironic; after all, 'A Large Search Company' helped put javascript on the map with its ... er... map.) The reasons for this have to do with the specific organizational incentives within 'A Large Search Company'. The short version is, there is an officiall supported 'A Large Search Company' js proto library, but it's bad and you should avoid it. There are two widely available alternatives: 'protobufjs' by the web assembly project, and 'pbf', by a prominent map software company ('xobpam' spell backwards, find it on github). We opt to use the 'xobmap'-spelled-backwards 'pbf' library because it aligns with our idiomatic js usage, has a very low footprint, and is production-tested at scale. In order to integrate 'xobpam'-spelled-backwards 'pbf' into our javascript codebase, we had to write some custom utilities, which we'd be happy to share. 

Another important note: being who they are, the stakeholders of 'A Large Search Company' will try to upsell you into using a bunch of value-add libraries alongside protocol buffers. In general, I advise a healthy suspicion of the value-adds. As is often the case, the best solution is to find reliable building blocks with very few moving parts, and hack them together by whatever means you can.

There are other alternatives to protocol buffers: 'parquet' and 'flatbuffers' are extension layers build on top of thrift and protocol buffers, respectively, and they each allow for efficient data access by natively storing data in a columnar fashion. 'parquet' is optimized for batch jobs on backend servers, whereas 'flatbuffers' is flexible and efficient enough to use for backend jobs or in-memory to power realtime computer graphics applications. 'spark''s 'distributed data sets' are also closely influenced by this model, and the implementation relies on 'thrift'. however, these libraries are more specialized and heavyweight than their ancestors 'proto' and 'thrift', and tend to have limited library support.

Based on our engineering feasiblity analysis in second-half 2020, all of this makes 'protocol buffers' the most effective choice for agnostic schema definitions.

TODO: add examples for usage in various languages, and simple utilities for type-checking csv's and json against proto definitions.

server/schemas/legacy/proto/graph/graph.proto

// graph.proto
//
// Overall container file for message definitions representing the evictorbook
// graph. As of 2020/12/29, the same schema is used to represent the live
// serving database as well as the intermediate graph databases which we use
// when generating our graph analysis, pruning nodes and edges, etc.
//
// Some fields, such as 'network_id' and 'c_id' (for component) are only
// populated and semantically meaningful after some analysis has been performed
// on the graph. This will hopefully be clear from context, and remains an
// ongoing effort to document thoroughly.
//
// Motivation: We use's neo4j's schemaless mode, to allow for flexibility in
// our scripts. This has its advantages, but it places significant cognitive
// load on developers who are using it. Because there is no explicit type
// safety mechanism, the burden of type safety is placed on the developer
// writing queries. As a result, it's fatiguing to write code that interacts
// with a schemaless persistence layer. More discouraging still, this situation
// can make it even more difficult than usual to write useful tests.
//
// The goal of these datastore-independent message schemas is to represent all
// of the graph node and relation types which appear in our graph db.
// Developers can use this interface definition file as an evolving reference,
// and use the auto-generated proto code as a guide to ensure type safety when
// writing code (in any language) that interacts with database artifacts.
//
// When reading from neo4j, we can pack the schemaless graph node data
// structures into these well-defined messages, and then proceed to manipulate
// that data with the benefit of static typing. Similarly, when writing to the
// database, our programs might first create an object using the protobuf
// library to ensuring type safety, and then copy that object's fields into the
// datastore to ensure no extraneous data is inadvertantly passed on.
//
// Defining messages in proto language also allows for schema evolution and
// backwards compatibility, which is a great benefit on an evolving project
// like evictorbook.

syntax = "proto3";

import "nodes.proto";
import "relations.proto";

package graph;

// Represents the complete contents of the evictorbook serving graph.
//
// TODO: Introduce a 'metadata' sub-message.
message Graph {
  // Container message for nodes in the graph.
  //
  // We present a wrapper message to have room to add additional fields which
  // are strongly associated with the node list (metadata, flags, etc).
  message NodeCollection {
    // list of nodes in the graph.
    repeated NodeDetails nodes = 1;
  }

  // Decribes the set of nodes in the graph, identified by unique string key.
  NodeCollection node_collection = 1;

  // Container message for relations in the graph.
  //
  // As with NodeCollection above, we present a wrapper message to reserve
  // space for add additional fields that are strongly associated with the
  // relation list (metadata, flags, etc).
  message RelationCollection {
    // list of relations in the graph, identified by the unique string keys of
    // the source and destination nodes.
    repeated RelationDetails relations = 1;
  }

  // Describes the set of relations (aka edges) among nodes in the graph.
  RelationCollection relation_collection = 2;
}

server/schemas/legacy/proto/graph/nodes.proto

// notes.proto
//
// This file contains message definitions representing the nodes in the
// evictorbook graph.
syntax = "proto3";

package graph;

// Represents a single node in the graph.
message NodeDetails {
  // internal graph db id for this node.
  int64 identity = 1;

  // the node types that this node has. in our graph, nodes always have a
  // single type, as of 2021/03/12, but this may change in the future.
  repeated string labels = 2;

  // the semantic type of the node, as an enum.
  NodeType type = 3;

  // a string key which uniquely identifies this node (among other nodes of its
  // type). each node type has a field which is designated as the unique key.
  // see definitions inline.
  //
  // TODO: annotate key fields in a machine-readable way.
  string unique_string_key = 4;

  // Describes the data payload of the node.
  //
  // set only the 'data' field which corresponds to the node's type,
  // specified above. see full message defintions below.
  oneof data {
    SFAssessorParcelData sf_assessor_parcel_data = 5;
    SFAssessorParcelOwnerData sf_assessor_parcel_owner_data = 6;
    CalSOSLPData cal_sos_limited_business_data = 7;
    CalSOSCorpData cal_sos_corporation_data = 8;
    CalSOSOwnerData cal_sos_business_owner_data = 9;
    SFRentBoardEvictionData sfrb_eviction_data = 10;
    SFRentBoardEvictorData sfrb_evictor_data = 11;
    AddressMainData address_main_data = 12;
    AddressUnitData address_unit_data = 13;
  }
}

// Types of entities that appear as nodes in the evictorbook-sf graph.
//
// Names of these values correspond directly to the strings used for tags in
// the evictorbook serving database, so they're terse and require some
// explanation.
//
// These names are 'namespaced' with prefixes depending on their source:
//  
//   prefix  |  source
//  -------------------------------------------
//   A       |  San Francisco Assessor's office
//   SOS     |  California Sec. of State business index
//   RB      |  SF Rent Board
//
// "Address" nodes have no namespace, and are generated when parsing
// documents from any source. In other words, the types which begin with
// "ADDRESS" have no implied data source.
//
// Below, you'll find message descriptions for the data payloads of each of
// these types. See those descriptions for more details.
enum NodeType {
  // Default value. Treat as unset.
  NODE_TYPE_UNSPECIFIED = 0;
  
  // Corresponds to node type "A_Parcel".
  //
  // Represents a physical parcel, as it's described in records from the SF
  // Assessor's office. Contains fields for the parcel's location and physical
  // characteristics. 
  A_PARCEL = 1;

  // Corresponds to node type "A_Parcel_Owner".
  A_PARCEL_OWNER = 2;

  // Corresponds to node type "SOS_LP".
    //
  // A limited partnership or an LLC, as it's represented in the California
  // Secretary of State business entity index.
  SOS_LP = 3;

  // Corresponds to node type "SOS_Corp".
  //
  // A for-profit corporation, as it's represented in the California Secretary
  // of State business entity index.
  SOS_CORP = 4;

  // Corresponds to node type "SOS_Owner".
  //
  // A person or business-entity which has an ownership interest in another
  // business-entity, as described in the California Secretary of State
  // business entity index.
  SOS_OWNER = 5;

  // Corresponds to node type "RB_Eviction".
  //
  // A record of an eviction which occurred in San Francisco, as represented in
  // SF Rent Board records.
  RB_EVICTION = 6;

  // Corresponds to node type "RB_Evictor".
  //
  // Represents a person or entity who instigated an eviction, according to
  // information from eviction records and/or sales transfer records.
  RB_EVICTOR = 7;

  // Corresponds to node type "Address_Main".
  //
  // Full address, without unit. May represent the address of a parcel's owner,
  // or an address associated with a business entity or one of its officers.
  //
  // The idea is to provide a single node that acts as a building or lot's
  // conceptual "anchor" node, while ADDRESS_UNIT nodes represent individual
  // units that can be resolved at that address.
  ADDRESS_MAIN = 8;

  // Corresponds to node type "Address_Unit".
  //
  // Full address, including a unit number if applicable. May represent the
  // address of a parcel's owner, or an address associated with a business
  // entity or one of its officers.
  //
  // Address_Unit graph nodes are analysed with connected component analysis,
  // and the network_id of the address's component is stored in this node.
  ADDRESS_UNIT = 9;
}


// Node type: A_Parcel
//
// Represents a physical parcel, as it's described in records from the SF
// Assessor's office. Contains fields for the parcel's location and physical
// characteristics. 
message SFAssessorParcelData {
  // Block lot string, which uniquely specifies a parcel in SF city and county
  // assessor records. This is a unique key for A_Parcel nodes in the database.
  string block_lot = 1;

  // Property class code according to the SF assessor's office.
  // For values and their definitions see:
  // https://data.sfgov.org/Housing-and-Buildings/Reference-Assessor-Recorder-Property-Class-Codes/pa56-ek2h/data
  string prop_class_code = 2;

  // TODO Confirm semantics. Full neighborhood name is stored as
  // 'neighborhood', below.
  string neighborhood_code = 3;

  // Identifier for the zoning district this parcel occupies.
  // San Francisco zoning district identifiers can be found here:
  // https://sfplanninggis.org/pim/map.html?layers=Zoning%20Districts
  string zone = 4;

  // Height of the buildings in this parcel, in stories.
  //
  // TODO: investigate behavior for multi-building parcels. 
  string stories = 5;

  // Number of units that occupy this real-estate parcel.
  string units = 6;

  // Number of rooms in the property on this parcel.
  string rooms = 7;

  // Number of bedrooms in the property on this parcel.
  string beds = 8;

  // Calendar year in which the buildings on this real-estate parcel were first
  // constructed.
  // TODO: confirm behavior for multi-unit parcels.
  string yr_built = 9;

  // Fields 11 to 16 are components of a structured address, as represented in 
  // county assessor records.

  // If the parcel occupies a single street number, this field contains that
  // street number. Otherwise, it contains the lowest street number in the
  // range of street  numbers that this parcel occupies.
  string parc_start_no = 10;

  // If this parcel occupies multiple street numbers, this field contains the 
  // highest street number in the range of occupied street numbers.
  //
  // TODO: Clarify behavior for single-street-number parcels.
  string parc_end_no = 11;

  // The name of the street of this parcel's address, as it appears in county
  // assessor records.
  string parc_street_name = 12;

  // Suffix of the street part of this parcel's address, as it appears in
  // county assessor records.
  string parc_street_type = 13;

  // Unit number component of this parcel's address, as it appears in county
  // assessor records.
  //
  // TODO Clarify behavior when the parcel has no subunits.
  string parc_unit_no = 14;

  // The zip code of this parcel's address, as it appears in county assessor
  // records.
  string parc_zip = 15;

  // Date on which this parcel's address was last updated, according to records
  // from the assessor's office.
  // Format: CCYYMMDD
  string update_date = 16;

  // Monetary value of the land this real-estate parcel occupies, according to
  // the most recent assessment on file, in US dollars.
  string assess_land_val = 17;

  // Monetary value of structures built on the land this parcel occupies,
  // according to the most recent assessment on file, in US collars.
  string assess_imp_val = 18;

  // Date on which the parcel's value was last assessed.
  // Format: CCYYMMDD
  string assess_val_date = 19;

  // TODO clarify the semantics here.
  // Units are in US dollars.
  string curr_sales_price = 20;

  // TODO clarify the semantics here.
  // Units are in US dollars.
  string curr_sales_date = 21;

  // Assessment of the rent-control status of this parcel:
  // 0 (default) if data unavailable to determine rent controlled status, 
  // 1 if likely rent controlled,
  // 2 if doubtful that this is rent controlled
  string rent_controlled = 22;

  // A string representing the parcel's street address, including street
  // number, street name and suffix, and unit number. The parcel is assumed to
  // be within SF city/county limits.
  //
  // Notes from schema definition sheet:
  // Full address in the format of "ST_START_NO-ST_END_NO ST_NAME ST_TYPE (Unit
  // UNIT)" (w/o end no if no address range, w/o parentheses if no unit)
  string addr = 23;

  // Longitude, in degrees, of a point within this parcel's boundaries.
  // string representing a floating-point number.
  string long = 24;

  // Latitude, in degrees, of a point within this parcel's boundaries.
  // string representing a floating-point number.
  string lat = 25;

  // Name of the neighborhood this parcel occupies. As of 2020/09/26, it's
  // assumed that all parcels are within SF city and county, so these are San
  // Francisco neighborhoods.
  //
  // Neighborhoods are assigned using SF polygons.
  //
  // Values correspond to names of the neighborhood polygons
  // described at:
  // https://data.sfgov.org/Geographic-Locations-and-Boundaries/SF-Find-Neighborhoods/pty2-tcw4
  string neighborhood = 26;
}

// Node type: A_Parcel_Owner
// 
// Describes an individual or entity that's directly listed, by name, as an
// owner of a parcel in SF Assessor records.
//
// NOTE: In the current schema, owners are uniquely identified by name, which
// introduces potential for false positives. This is a property of the schema
// that we should revisit for future revisions.
message SFAssessorParcelOwnerData {
  // Name of owner listed on parcel.
  //
  // TODO Briefly describe how/whether this data was normalized.
  string owner_name = 1;
}

// Node type: SOS_LP
//
// A limited partnership or an LLC, as decribed in the Calif. Sec. of State
// business entity index.
message CalSOSLPData {
  // Normalized name of the partnership or llc, derived from the name used in
  // Calif Sec. of State business records.
  //
  // TODO: Describe or link specifics of the string normalization.
  string name_norm = 1;

  // LLC only: state or county for formation of foreign llc.
  string jurisdiction_llc = 2;
 
  // LLC only: management structure.
  // 1 = One Manager
  // M = More Than One Manager
  // A = All Members are Managers
  // LLC ONLY
  string llc_management_code = 3;

  // LLC only: type of business.
  string llc_type_of_business = 4;

  // Format is CCYYJJJN9999
  // CCYY = Century and Year.
  // JJJ = Julian day of year.
  // N = Record Type
  // 0 = LP Record
  // 1 = LLC Record
  // 9999 = Sequence Number 
  string file_number = 5;

  // Date of initial filing, represented as CCYYMMDD
  string file_date = 6;

  //  Identifies current status of LP/LLC
  //  A = Active
  //  B = Dishonored Check
  //  C = Canceled
  //  D = Dissolved
  //  P = Pending Cancellation
  //  F = Franchise Tax Board (FTB) Suspended/Forfeited
  //  M = Merged out
  //  O = Converted out
  //  S = Secretary of State (SOS) Suspended/Forfeited
  //  2 = SOS/FTB Suspended/Forfeited
  string status = 7; 

  // Filing type: foreign "F" or domestic "D".
  string filing_type = 8;

  // California Limited Partnership or LLC Name, non-normalized.
  string name = 9;

  // State or country of formation for foreign limited partnerships.
  string jurisdiction = 10;

  // Agent of service contact info.
  //
  // !! CAUTION !! These fields follow a different naming convention than their
  // conterparts in SOS_Corp.
  string agent_name = 11;
  string agent_address_1 = 12;
  string agent_address_2 = 13;
  string agent_city = 14;
  string agent_state = 15;
  string agent_zip = 16;

  // Date or cause of termination.
  //
  // This is a free-form text field and can follow many formats, depending on
  // context. Examples of typical contents:
  //
  //  - date in "MM/DD/YY" format. some records allow '00' for month or date.
  //  - date in "MM/DD/YY" format with qualifying suffix.
  //       examples: "01/01/15 OR EVENT", "01/15/40 OR PER AGMT", "02/15/33*"
  //  - date in "MMDDYY" format
  //  - date in "MM/DD/YYYY" format (for some 90's records).
  //
  // In general, if you're looking at this, expect it to be difficult to parse.
  //
  // TODO: document exhaustively and/or apply cleanup in pipeline.
  string term = 17;

  // Business entity component id, generated by the evictorbook data pipeline
  // via connected component analysis.
  //
  // Each SOS_Corp and SOS_LP graph node in the graph is assigned a 'c_id'.
  //
  // Two SOS_Corp and/or SOS_LP graph nodes share a c_id if there exists a
  // path connecting those graph nodes in the subgraph of {SOS_Corp|SOS_LP}
  // graph nodes and {OFFICER_FOR} edges.
  //
  // See the developer guide for a detailed description of the evictorbook's
  // network connection methodology in the section "Network Connection Method -
  // Detailed > During DB Creation". As of 2020/09/09, c_id assignment is
  // described in step 'I' of that section.
  int64 c_id = 18;

  // Network component id of the connected component this owner belongs to.
  // This uniquely specifies the ownership network this owner belongs to,
  // according to connected component analysis in the evictorbook data
  // pipeline.
  //
  // 'network_id' components are aggregations of one or more 'c_id'
  // components, connected by a path in the subgraph described above.
  //
  // So, graph nodes that share a 'c_id' also share a 'network_id', but graph
  // nodes that share a 'network_id' do NOT NECESSARILY share a 'c_id'.
  //
  // See the developer guide for a detailed description of the evictorbook's
  // network connection methodology in the section "Network Connection Method -
  // Detailed > During DB Creation". As of 2020/09/09, network_id assignment is
  // described in step 'III'. of that section.
  int64 network_id = 19;
}

// Node type: SOS_Corp
//
// A corporation, as described in the Calif. Sec. of State business entity
// index.
message CalSOSCorpData {
  // Normalized name of the business, derived from the name in Calif. Sec. of
  // State business records.
  //
  // TODO: Describe or link specifics of the string normalization.
  string name_norm = 1;

  // Transaction date of the document which established this corporation,
  // according to the California Secretary of State business registry.
  //
  // Date is represented as a string with format 'CCYYMMDD'.
  string transaction_date = 2;

  // An 8 digit Corporate Identification Number, from the California Secretary
  // of State business registry.
  string corporation_number = 3;

  // Date on which this corporation was incorporated, according to the
  // California Secretary of State business registry.
  //
  // Date is represented as a string with format 'CCYYMMDD'.
  string incorporation_date = 4;

  // Status of the corporation, as a string containing a code from Calif. Sec.
  // of State business entity records. The values are described as follows in
  // the database schema documentation:
  //
  // 1 = Active
  // 2 = Suspended
  // 3 = Canceled
  // 4 = Surrendered
  // 5 = Term expired
  // 6 = Dissolved
  // 7 = Forfeited
  // 8 = Deleted
  // 9 = Inactive
  // C = Merged Out
  // E = State to Federal Bank Conversion
  // F = Conditionally dissolved (No tax clearance)
  // Not sure about code = Converted Out
  //
  // In the 05/2020 production database, the codes which appear are: "0"-"9", "C"
  string corporation_status = 5;

  // Description of the legal process used to establish this corporation,
  // according to Calif. Sec. of state records. The allowed values and their
  // meanings are listed below.
  //
  // ARTS = Articles of Incorporation
  // S&DC = Statement & Designation By Foreign Corporation
  // S&DA = Statement & Designation By Foreign Association
  // FNRE = Foreign Name Registration
  //
  // present in 05/2020 production database: "ARTS", "S&DC".
  string corporation_type = 6;

  // Description of the tax-base of the corporation, according to calif. sec.
  // of state records. this indicates whether a corporation is for-profit or
  // non-profit.
  //
  // S = Stock
  // N = Non-Stock (Nonprofit)
  string corporation_tax_base = 7;

  // Additional corporate classifications which may convey special status, such
  // as 'religious' or 'agricultural cooperative' according to calif. sec. of
  // state business entity records.
  //
  // AG = Agricultural Cooperative
  // CR = Credit Union
  // MU = Mutual Benefit
  // OC = Other Cooperative
  // PB = Public Benefit
  // RE = Religious
  // SL = Corporation Sole
  // UN = Unclassified
  string corporation_classification = 8;

  // Limited Term expiration date. Format = CCYYMMDD
  string term_expiration_date = 9;

  // Describes whether this corporation is in good standing with the california
  // franchise tax board (ftb).
  //
  // '' = Not Suspended (In Good Standing) (empty string)
  // F = Forfeited
  // S = Suspended
  string ftb_suspension_status = 10;

  // If this corporation has been subject to action by the franchise tax board
  // as described in 'ftb_suspension_status", then this field contains a string
  // representation of the date of that action.
  //
  // Date is represented as a string with format 'CCYYMMDD'.
  string ftb_suspension_date = 11;

  // Statement of information file number, per calif sec of state records.
  string so_file_number = 12;

  // Last complete statement (of information?) file date.
  //
  // Date is represented as a string with format 'CCYYMMDD'.
  string so_file_date = 13;

  // Name of corporation, directly from calif. sec. of state records without
  // normalization.
  string corporation_name = 14;

  // 'Care of' Name, meaning the 'c/o' addressee which should be included on
  // mail intended for the corporation.
  string co_name = 15;

  // Name and contact info of Agent for Service of Process
  //
  // !!! CAUTION !!! Different naming conventions from SOS_LP fields with
  // similar info!
  string agent_name = 16;
  string agent_address_line_1 = 17;
  string agent_address_line_2 = 18;
  string agent_address_city = 19;

  // The state component of the agent-for-service addr.
  //
  // NOTE: These are not cleaned! Most corps have value "CA", but some have
  // suffixes (intended to indicate county code?)
  //
  // examples of odd entries in 05/2020 production db:
  //    "CA 9", "CA 5126", "CAA", "A".
  string agent_address_state_county = 20;

  // Sometimes these are 5-digit codes, sometimes these are 9-digit.
  // TODO: cleanup.
  string agent_address_zip_code = 21;

  // TODO: Describe this field; there's no description in the schema document.
  //
  // As of 2020/09/09, working understanding is that if the corporation is not
  // 'domestic' (internal to calif.), then this field describes a u.s. state
  // other than california, or a country outside the u.s., where this
  // corporation originated.
  string state_or_foreign_country = 22;

  // Business entity component id, generated by the evictorbook data pipeline
  // via connected component analysis.
  //
  // Each SOS_Corp and SOS_LP graph node in the graph is assigned a 'c_id'.
  //
  // Two SOS_Corp and/or SOS_LP graph nodes share a c_id if there exists a
  // path connecting those graph nodes in the subgraph of {SOS_Corp|SOS_LP}
  // graph nodes and {OFFICER_FOR} edges.
  //
  // See the developer guide for a detailed description of the evictorbook's
  // network connection methodology in the section "Network Connection Method -
  // Detailed > During DB Creation". As of 2020/09/09, c_id assignment is
  // described in step 'I' of that section.
  int64 c_id = 23;

  // Parcel ownership network component id, generated by the evictorbook data
  // pipeline via connected component analysis.
  //
  // SOS_Corp, SOS_LP, and SOS_Owner graph nodes are required to have a
  // network_id, and Address_Unit graph nodes may optionally have a
  // network_id. 
  //
  // Two graph nodes share a network_id if there is a path connecting those
  // graph nodes in the subgraph of {SOS_Corp|SOS_LP|SOS_Owner|Address_Unit}
  // graph nodes and { OFFICER_FOR | ENTITY_OWNED BY | LISTED_AT } edges.
  //
  // 'network_id' components are aggregations of one or more 'c_id'
  // components, connected by a path in the subgraph described above.
  //
  // So, graph nodes that share a 'c_id' also share a 'network_id', but graph
  // nodes that share a 'network_id' do NOT NECESSARILY share a 'c_id'.
  //
  // See the developer guide for a detailed description of the evictorbook's
  // network connection methodology in the section "Network Connection Method -
  // Detailed > During DB Creation". As of 2020/09/09, network_id assignment is
  // described in step 'III'. of that section.
  int64 network_id = 24;
}

// Node type: SOS_Owner
//
// A person or business-entity which has an ownership interest in another
// business-entity.
//
// NOTE: Need clarification on how this related to 'ENTITY_OWNED_BY' -- it
// seems as though if both nodes in the ENTITY_OWNED_BY relationship are
// business-entities, then would be difficult to tell which entity owns the
// other. Might be missing something here. -dee 10/2020
message CalSOSOwnerData {
  // Normalized name of the person or entity who's a stakeholder in a
  // corporation or limited partnership.
  //
  // TODO: Describe or link specifics of the string normalization.
  string name_norm = 1;

  // Network component id of the connected component this owner belongs to.
  // This uniquely specifies the ownership network this owner belongs to,
  // according to connected component analysis in the evictorbook data
  // pipeline.
  //
  // For more info about network component id's assigned in the evictorbook
  // graph, see documentation on 'c_id' and 'network_id' in CalSOSLPData and
  // CalSOSCorpData.
  //
  // See the developer guide for a detailed description of the evictorbook's
  // network connection methodology in the section "Network Connection Method -
  // Detailed > During DB Creation". As of 2020/09/09, network_id assignment is
  // described in step 'III'. of that section.
  int64 network_id = 2;
}

// Node type: RB_Eviction
//
// A record of an eviction which occurred in San Francisco, as represented in
// SF Rent Board records.
message SFRentBoardEvictionData {
  // Eviction ID, unique in aemp's records.
  // 
  // IMPORTANT:  This is derived from the petition ID of the eviction in rent
  // board records, but in some cases it's appended with a suffix. Therefore,
  // it *cannot* safely be used for direct string comparison with RB records.
  //
  // TODO: Document the specifics of the eviction ID suffixes.
  //
  // TODO: Mitigate the impact of the ID shift by preserving the raw petition
  // id in this node.
  string evict_id = 1;

  // Format: CCYYMMDD
  string evict_date = 2;

  // Buyout amount in USD, if applicable.
  string amount = 3;

  // Number of units whose occupants were evicted, if known.
  string units = 4;

  // Type of eviction, for example "Buyout Declaration" or "Ellis Act
  // Withdrawal".
  //
  // TODO: Enumerate all legal values here. Eventually, consider replacing
  // this with an enum.
  string type = 5;

  // Attributed evictors according to ellis act withdrawal records. Only
  // populated for evictions of type "Ellis Act Withdrawal".
  //
  // TODO Verify semantics. Ad-hoc testing on EB Web shows a list of multiple
  // ellis evictors, which appear to be derived from interpreting a string as a
  // comma-separated list. As of 2020/09/09, the relationship between this
  // string and the EB Web api is not well documented.
  string ellis_evictor = 6;
}

// Node type: RB_Evictor 
//
// Represents a person or entity who instigated an eviction, according to
// information from sales transfer records.
message SFRentBoardEvictorData {
  // Name of the entity that instigated the eviction, as it appears in
  // documents relating to the eviction. This may be an individual or a
  // business.
  //
  // TODO Describe whether and how this string was normalized.
  string evictor = 1;
}

// Node type: Address_Main
//
// Full address, without unit. May represent the address of a parcel's owner,
// or an address associated with a business entity or one of its officers.
//
// 'Address_Main' represents a conceptual 'anchor' or entry point for all
// possible units at a given top-level street address. In contrast, its
// counterpart 'Address_Unit' represents a 'resolved' address that can
// actually be contacted, with unit number if applicable. See details in
// Address_Unit description below.
//
// TODO: Consider a structured representation of the address for more robust
// comparisons.
message AddressMainData {
  // The address, represented as a single string.
  //
  // TODO: Describe format guidelines -- does this need a city and zip, for
  // example?
  //
  // TODO: Describe whether and how this string was normalized.
  string addr = 1;
}

// Node type: Address_Unit
//
// Represents a resolved address, with unit number if necessary, which can be
// contacted by mail or visited in person. May represent the address of a
// parcel's owner, or an address associated with a business entity or one of
// its officers.
//
// This node exists even for addresses which contain only a single unit. See
// description of Address_Main above. Single-unit addresses are considered to
// be a special case, where the conceptual 'main' address happens to
// correspond to the 'resolved' (unit-level) address.
//
// Address_Unit graph nodes are analysed with connected component analysis,
// and the network_id of the address's component is stored in this node.
//
// TODO: Consider a structured representation for more robust comparisons, as
// with Address_Main above.
message AddressUnitData {
  // The address, represented as a single string.
  //
  // TODO: Describe format guidelines -- does this need a city and zip, for
  // example?
  //
  // TODO: Describe whether and how this string was normalized.
  string addr = 1;

  // Network component id of the business-network component which is primarily
  // associated with this unit-level address.
  //
  // These network component id's are assigned during component analysis in the
  // evictorbook data pipeline.
  //
  // For more info about network component id's assigned in the evictorbook
  // graph, see documentation on 'c_id' and 'network_id' in CalSOSLPData and
  // CalSOSCorpData messages.
  //
  // See the developer guide for a detailed description of the evictorbook's
  // network connection methodology in the section "Network Connection Method -
  // Detailed > During DB Creation". As of 2020/09/09, network_id assignment is
  // described in step 'III'. of that section.
  int64 network_id = 2;
}

server/schemas/legacy/proto/graph/relations.proto

// relations.proto
//
// This file contains message definitions that conceptually represent the
// relations (edges) connecting nodes in the evictorbook graph database. 
syntax = "proto3";

package graph;

// Represents a single relation (edge) in the graph.
message RelationDetails {
  ////////////////////////////////////////////
  // fields representing neo4j db internals:
  ////////////////////////////////////////////

  // string containing the type of the relation.
  string type = 1;

  // internal neo4j id for the start node.
  int64 start_identity = 2;

  // internal neo4j id for the end node.
  int64 end_identity = 3;

  ////////////////////////////////////////////
  // fields representing eb graph semantics: 
  ////////////////////////////////////////////

  // type, as an enum specific to eb graph semantics. the value names of this
  // enum correspond to the string values used for 'type'.
  RelationType relation_type = 4;

  // semantic unique key for start node.
  string start_string_key = 5;

  // semantic unique string key for end node (destination).
  string end_string_key = 6;

  // data payload. describes annotations on the graph relations (such as
  // weights on an edge, or additional properties or flags).
  // 
  // for relation types with no annotations, we define a placeholder message so
  // there's a place to add them if needed.
  oneof data {
    EvictedByRelationData evicted_by_relation_data = 7;
    EvictionAtRelationData eviction_located_at_relation_data = 8;
    ListedAtRelationData business_listed_at_relation_data = 9;
    EntityOwnedByRelationData business_entity_owned_by_relation_data = 10;
    OfficerForRelationData business_officer_for_relation_data = 11;
    BELinkedToRelationData
        owner_or_evictor_linked_to_business_relation_data = 12;
    ParcOwnedByRelationData parcel_owned_by_relation_data = 13;
    UnitAtRelationData unit_at_relation_data = 14;
    ParcelOwnerAtAddressRelationData
        parcel_owner_at_address_relation_data = 15;
  }
}

// RelationType
//
// Type enum for the potential connections between nodes in the ebook graph.
// For more details see comments on the 'RelationData' messages below.
enum RelationType {
  // Default value. Treat as unset.
  RELATION_TYPE_UNSPECIFIED = 0;

  // Relation type: EVICTED_BY
  //
  // Represents a hypothesis attributing an individual for being responsible in
  // insigating an eviction.
  //
  // See EvictedByRelationData description for details.
  EVICTED_BY = 1;

  // Relation type: EVICTION_AT
  //
  // Associates an SF Rent Board eviction record with the dwelling from which
  // one or more tenants were evicted.
  //
  // See EvictionAtRelationData description for details.
  EVICTION_AT = 2;

  // Relation type: LISTED_AT
  //
  // Describes an address associated with a business entity in Secretary of
  // state records.
  //
  // See ListedAtRelationData description for details.
  LISTED_AT = 3;
  
  // Relation type: ENTITY_OWNED_BY
  //
  // Indicates that an SOS_Owner has a stake in a SOS business entity (the
  // target entity may be either a limited business (LP) or a corporation
  // (Corp)).
  //
  // See EntityOwnedByRelationData description for details.
  ENTITY_OWNED_BY = 4;

  // Relation type: OFFICER_FOR
  //
  // Indicates that one business entity is an officer for another business
  // entity (which seems pretty weird).
  //
  // See OfficerForRelationData description for details.
  OFFICER_FOR = 5;

  // Relation type: BE_LINKED_TO
  //
  // Connects a business node (SOS_Corp or SOS_LP) to a parcel-owner or
  // attributed evictor (A_Parcel_Owner or RB_Evictor).
  //
  // The A_Parcel_Owner or RB_Evictor is considered to *be* the business. That
  // is, this means we believe the business is the same entity as the reported
  // owner or evictor. This is based on string matching the names of the
  // recorded owner/attributed evictor with the names of businesses from
  // california sec. of state business data.
  //
  // See BELinkedToRelationData description for details.
  BE_LINKED_TO = 6;

  // Relation type: PARC_OWNED_BY
  //
  // Describes a direct owner relationship between a parcel and an
  // individual/entity that's listed as an owner via assessor property tax
  // records.
  //
  // See ParcelOwnedByRelationData description for details.
  PARC_OWNED_BY = 7;

  // Relation type: UNIT_AT
  //
  // Indicates that an Address_Unit node correponds to the main parcel address
  // at Address_Main.
  //
  // See UnitAtRelationData description for details.
  UNIT_AT = 8;

  // Relation type: PARC_OWNER_ADDR_AT
  //
  // Indicates that a parcel owner can be reached at this mailing address.
  // TODO: Clarify, does this mean the address is listed as owner occupied? Or
  // is this derived from some other signal?
  //
  // See ParcelOwnerAtAddressRelationData description for details.
  PARC_OWNER_ADDR_AT = 9;
}

// Relation type: EVICTED_BY
//
// Represents a hypothesis attributing an individual for being responsible in
// insigating an eviction.
//
// Start node: RB_Eviction node describing SF Rent Board eviction record,
// keyed by unique id. Note that evictorbook graph unique ID's for evictions
// may differ from id's in other databases because a one-character suffix is
// sometimes appended. TODO: Describe details.
//
// End node: RB_Evictor node describing an individual believed to be
// responsible for instigating the eviction.
message EvictedByRelationData {
  // todo clarify semantics.
  bool multiple_sales_matches = 1;
}

// Relation type: EVICTION_AT
//
// Associates an SF Rent Board eviction record with the dwelling from which
// one or more tenants were evicted.
//
// Start node: RB_Eviction node describing SF Rent Board eviction record,
// keyed by unique id. See caveat on eviction id's in comments for
// EvictedByRelationData, above.
//
// End node: A_Parcel node, describing a parcel from SF Assessor
// records, keyed by the parcel's unique "block lot".
message EvictionAtRelationData {
  // todo clarify semantics.
  bool multiple_addr_matches = 1;
}

// Relation type: LISTED_AT
//
// Describes an address associated with a business entity in Secretary of
// state records.
//
// TODO: Clarify the semantic meaning of this address; I believe it's a
// mailing address but need to confirm.
//
// Start node: SOS_Corp or SOS_LP node, identified by its unique normalized
// business name in the California Sec. of State business registry.
//
// End node: Address_Unit describing a unit-level address at which
// this business entity can be contacted.
//
// Empty as of 2020/12/29, as the relation carries no data payload other than
// the fact of its own presence.
message ListedAtRelationData {
}

// Relation type: ENTITY_OWNED_BY
//
// Indicates that an SOS_Owner has a stake in a SOS business entity (the
// target entity may be either a limited business (LP) or a corporation
// (Corp)).
//
// Start node: SOS_Corp or SOS_LP node, identified by its unique normalized
// business name in the California Sec. of State business registry.
//
// End node: SOS_Owner node, identified by the normalized name of that
// owner in the California Sec. of State business registry.
//
// NOTE: This collapsing of all identically-named owners in the business
// registry is the likely the source of over-connections in our graph
// methodology, and is on the list of items to revisit as we revise the
// pipeline.
//
// Empty as of 2020/12/29, as the relation carries no data payload other than
// the fact of its own presence.
message EntityOwnedByRelationData {
}

// Relation type: OFFICER_FOR
//
// Indicates that one business entity is an officer for another business
// entity (which seems pretty weird).
//
// Start node: The 'serving' SOS_LP or SOS_Corp node, identified by its
// unique business name in the California Sec. of State business index.
//
// End: The 'served at' SOS_LP or SOS_Corp node, identified by the
// same means as the start node.
//
// Empty as of 2020/12/29, as the relation carries no data payload other than
// the fact of its own presence.
message OfficerForRelationData {
}

// Relation type: BE_LINKED_TO
//
// Connects a business node (SOS_Corp or SOS_LP) to a parcel-owner or
// attributed evictor (A_Parcel_Owner or RB_Evictor).
//
// The A_Parcel_Owner or RB_Evictor is considered to *be* the business. That
// is, this means we believe the business is the same entity as the reported
// owner or evictor. This is based on string matching the names of the
// recorded owner/attributed evictor with the names of businesses from
// california sec. of state business data.
//
// Start node: RB_Evictor or A_Parcel_Owner node, identifying an agent
// believed to have instigated an eviction from SF Rent Board records, or a
// property-holding entity described in SF Assessor data.
//
// End node: SOS_LP or SOS_Corp node representing a business entity in
// California Sec of State index, which is believed to be acting in the role of
// parcel owner or attributed evictor.
//
// Empty, as this relation carries no data payload other than the fact of its
// own presence.
message BELinkedToRelationData {
}

// Relation type: PARC_OWNED_BY
//
// Describes a direct owner relationship between a parcel and an
// individual/entity that's listed as an owner via assessor property tax
// records.
//
// Start node: A_Parcel node from SF Assessor records, identified by 'block
// lot'.
//
// End node: A_Parcel_Owner node from SF Assessor records, identified
// by name directly in the documentation for the start node's real-estate
// parcel.
message ParcOwnedByRelationData {
  // Ownership percentage documented in SF Assessor records, expressed as an
  // integer between 0 and 100, inclusive.
    int32 perc_owner = 1;

  // Date in CCYYMMDD of the documents in SF Assessor records which
  // demonstrate this ownership.
    string record_date = 2;
}

// Relation type: UNIT_AT
//
// Indicates that an Address_Unit node correponds to the main parcel address
// at Address_Main.
//
// This edge exists even for addresses which contain only a single unit. The
// reason is that 'Address_Main' nodes conceptually represent the entire set
// of possible units at that street address, whereas 'Address_Unit' nodes
// represent a resolved address that can actually be contacted. Single-unit
// addresses are considered to be a special case where there happens to be a
// one-to-one correspondence between the two.
//
// Start node: Address_Unit node representing a definite, contactable address
// complete with unit number. TODO: Describe formatting of that node's key.
//
// End node: Address_Main node, identified by an address with the unit
// information scrubbed, which represents all potential units at that street
// address. TODO: Describe formatting of that node's key.
//
// Empty as of 2020/12/29, as the relation carries no data payload other than
// the fact of its own presence.
message UnitAtRelationData {
}

// Relation type: PARC_OWNER_ADDR_AT
//
// Indicates that a parcel owner can be reached at this mailing address.
//
// TODO: Clarify whether this indicates the address was listed as
// owner-occupied, as this may be relevant information.
//
// Start node: A_Parcel_Owner node, describing a property owner identified by
// name in SF Assessor records.
//
// End node: Address_Unit node representing a resolved street address, with
// unit number if applicable. SF Assessor records indicate that the owner can
// be contacted by mail at this address.
//
// Empty as of 2020/12/29, as the relation carries no data payload other than
// the fact of its own presence.
message ParcelOwnerAtAddressRelationData {
}

server/schemas/legacy/proto/query/business.proto

// query/business.proto
//
// contains messages related to corporations and other businesses from the
// calif sec. of state business registry, as they appear in ebook's query
// abstraction layer.
syntax = "proto3";

package query;

////////////////////////////////////////
//  corp / lp / business  messages
////////////////////////////////////////

// fields in this message correspond to fields of the same name in SOS_Corp
// vertices in the neo4j schema. proto messages describing that schema are
// found in the graph/ directory.
//
// as of 2020/09/26, this is a direct clone of the graph node schema, with one
// exception: this message is missing the normalized corporation name
// 'name_norm', which serves as a unique key. although the two are currently
// very similar, we prefer to define two separate messages to allow for the
// schema and the query abstraction to evolve independently.
message CalSOSCorporationDetails {
  // transaction date of the document which established this corporation,
  // according to the california secretary of state business registry.
  // 
  // format: 'CCMMYYDD'.
  string transaction_date = 1;

  // an 8 digit corporate identification number, from the california secretary
  // of state business registry.
  string corporation_number = 2;

  // date on which this corporation was incorporated, according to the
  // california secretary of state business registry.
  // format: 'CCYYMMDD'
  string incorporation_date = 3;

  // status of the corporation, as a string containing a code from calif. sec.
  // of state business entity records. The values are described as follows in
  // the database schema documentation:
  //
  // 1 = Active
  // 2 = Suspended
  // 3 = Canceled
  // 4 = Surrendered
  // 5 = Term expired
  // 6 = Dissolved
  // 7 = Forfeited
  // 8 = Deleted
  // 9 = Inactive
  // C = Merged Out
  // E = State to Federal Bank Conversion
  // F = Conditionally dissolved (No tax clearance)
  // Not sure about code = Converted Out
  string corporation_status = 4;

  // description of the legal process used to establish this corporation,
  // according to Calif. Sec. of state records. The allowed values and their
  // meanings are listed below.
  //
  // ARTS = Articles of Incorporation
  // S&DC = Statement & Designation By Foreign Corporation
  // S&DA = Statement & Designation By Foreign Association
  // FNRE = Foreign Name Registration
  string corporation_type = 5;

  // description of the tax-base of the corporation, according to calif. sec.
  // of state records. this indicates whether a corporation is for-profit or
  // non-profit.
  //
  // S = Stock
  // N = Non-Stock (Nonprofit)
  string corporation_tax_base = 6;

  // additional corporate classifications which may convey special status, such
  // as 'religious' or 'agricultural cooperative' according to calif. sec. of
  // state business entity records.
  //
  // G = Agricultural Cooperative
  // CR = Credit Union
  // MU = Mutual Benefit
  // OC = Other Cooperative
  // PB = Public Benefit
  // RE = Religious
  // SL = Corporation Sole
  // UN = Unclassified
  string corporation_classification = 7;

  // limited term expiration date.
  // TODO: describe what this means.
  // format: 'CCYYMMDD'
  string term_expiration_date = 8;

  // describes whether this corporation is in good standing with the california
  // franchise tax board (ftb).
  //
  // â€˜ â€˜ (Blank) = Not Suspended (In Good Standing)
  // F = Forfeited
  // S = Suspended
  string ftb_suspension_status = 9;

  // if this corporation has been subject to action by the franchise tax board
  // as described in 'ftb_suspension_status', then this field contains a string
  // representation of the date of that action.
  //
  // format: 'CCYYMMDD'
  string ftb_suspension_date = 10;

  // statement of information file number, per calif sec of state records.
  string so_file_number = 11;

  // last complete statement (of information?) file date.
  // format: 'CCYYMMDD'
  string so_file_date = 12;

  // name of corporation, directly from calif. sec. of state records without
  // normalization.
  string corporation_name = 13;

  // 'care of' name, meaning the 'c/o' addressee which should be included on
  // mail intended for the corporation.
  string co_name = 14;

  // name of agent of process, as it appears on mailing address.
  string agent_name = 15;

  // mailing address for agent of process, line 1.
  string agent_address_line_1 = 16;

  // mailing address for agent of process, line 2.
  string agent_address_line_2 = 17;

  // city component of agent of process's mailing address.
  string agent_address_city = 18;

  // todo: clarify what this means. is it state or county? or both????
  string agent_address_state_county = 19;

  // todo: clarify whether these are 5-digit or 9-digit postal codes.
  string agent_address_zip_code = 20;

  // if the corporation is not 'domestic' (internal to calif.), then this field
  // specified a u.s. state other than california, or a country outside the
  // u.s., where this corporation originated.
  string state_or_foreign_country = 23;

  // business entity component id, generated by the evictorbook data pipeline
  // via connected component analysis.
  //
  // See comments inline in BusinessNetworkIdentifier from network.proto for
  // a detailed explanation.
  int64 c_id = 24;

  // parcel ownership network component id, generated by the evictorbook data
  // pipeline via connected component analysis.
  //
  // SOS_Corp, SOS_LP, and SOS_Owner vertices are required to have a
  // network_id, and Address_Unit vertices may optionally have a network_id. 
  //
  // See comments inline in BusinessNetworkIdentifier from network.proto for
  // a detailed explanation.
  int64 network_id = 25;
}

// closely follows CalSOSLimitedBusinessData in the graph proto defintion.
// we define a message here, to allow for the graph schema and the query
// abstraction to evolve separately.
message CalSOSLimitedBusinessDetails {
  // llc only: state or county for formation of foreign llc.
  //
  // TODO: confirm/deny that this is unset for messages representing limited
  // partnerships.
  string jurisdiction_llc = 1;
 
  // llc only: management structure.
  //
  // 1 = One Manager
  // M = More Than One Manager
  // A = All Members are Managers
  //
  // todo: confirm/deny that this is unset for messages representing limited
  // partnerships.
  string llc_management_code = 2;

  // llc only: type of business.
  // todo: provide examples.
  // todo: confirm/deny that this is unset for messages representing limited
  // partnerships.
  string llc_type_of_business = 3;

  // the filing number of the business entity, which is derived from the date
  // on which its filing paperwork was filed. the number is presented as a
  // string, with the format described below:
  //
  // format: 'CCYYJJJN9999'
  //   CCYY = century and year
  //   JJJ = julian day of year
  //   N = record type:
  //       0 = lp record
  //       1 = llc record
  //   9999 = sequence number 
  string file_number = 4;

  // date of original filing for this business. represents the same calendar
  // date as the date component of file_number, but follows a different format.
  // format: 'CCYYMMDD'
  string file_date = 5;

  //  identifies current status of lp/llc, as represented in calif. sec. of
  //  state business entity records.
  //
  //  A : active
  //  B : dishonored check
  //  C : canceled
  //  D : dissolved
  //  P : pending cancellation
  //  F : franchise tax board (ftb) suspended/forfeited
  //  M : merged out
  //  O : converted out
  //  S : secretary of state (sos) suspended/forfeited
  //  2 : sos/ftb suspended/forfeited
  string status = 6; 

  // filing type (foreign or domestic) of this lp or llc, as represented in
  // calif. sec. of state business entity registry. 
  //
  // todo: clarify behavior for partnerships that originate from other u.s.
  // states.
  // todo: clarify the precise values that can be returned by the database.
  string filing_type = 7;

  // the raw, non-normalized name of this calif. limited partnership or llc,
  // as represented in calif. sec. of state business entity registry.
  string name = 8;

  // state or country of formation for foreign limited partnerships.
  string jurisdiction = 9;

  // name of agent of process, as it appears on mailing address.
  string agent_name = 10;

  // mailing address for agent of process, line 1.
  //
  // CAUTION: naming convention differs from similar field in corp details.
  string agent_address_1 = 11;

  // mailing address for agent of process, line 2.
  //
  // CAUTION: naming convention differs from similar field in corp details.
  string agent_address_2 = 12;

  // city component of agent of process's mailing address.
  //
  // CAUTION: naming convention differs from similar field in corp details.
  string agent_city = 13;

  // component of agent of process's mailing address.
  //
  // CAUTION: naming convention differs from similar field in corp details.
  string agent_state = 14;

  // todo: clarify whether these are 5-digit or 9-digit postal codes.
  //
  // CAUTION: naming convention differs from similar field in corp details.
  string agent_zip = 15;

  // cause of termination, if this lp/llc has been terminated. 
  // todo: add examples.
  string term = 16;

  // business entity component id, generated by the evictorbook data pipeline
  // via connected component analysis.
  //
  // see comments inline in BusinessNetworkIdentifier from network.proto for
  // a detailed explanation.
  int64 c_id = 17;

  // parcel ownership network component id, generated by the evictorbook data
  // pipeline via connected component analysis.
  //
  // SOS_Corp, SOS_LP, and SOS_Owner nodes are required to have a network_id,
  // and Address_Unit nodes may optionally have a network_id. 
  //
  // see comments inline in BusinessNetworkIdentifier from network.proto for
  // a detailed explanation.
  int64 network_id = 18;
}

server/schemas/legacy/proto/query/eviction.proto

// query/eviction.proto
//
// contains messages related to eviction records as they appear in the
// query-layer abstraction of ebook's serving js. 
syntax = "proto3";

import "network.proto";

package query;

////////////////////////
//  eviction messages
////////////////////////

// consolidated info about an eviction in sf rent board records. 
//
// as of 2020/09/26, there are two flavors of eviction structs in ebook
// queries. this message describes the union of those structs, and is used to
// represent both.
//
// eviction details in location-based query results (neighborhood.js) include
// info about the attributed evictor and their business network.
//
// that info is not present in business-based query results (corp.js, et al),
// so those fields are left unset. see comments inline.
message SFRBEvictionMetadata {
  //////////////////////////////////////////////////////
  // fields describing the eviction record itself:
  //////////////////////////////////////////////////////

  // unique id for RB_Eviction nodes in ebook dataset.
  //
  // this is typically derived from sf rent board's petition id, but is *NOT*
  // equivalent. DO NOT USE THIS FOR DIRECT COMPARISON TO SFRB RECORDS.
  string evict_id = 1;

  // date on which this eviction took effect, according to public records.
  // format: 'CCYYMMDD'.
  string evict_date = 2;

  // type of eviction, for example "Buyout Declaration" or "Ellis Act
  // Withdrawal".  todo: document supported values for this field.
  string type = 3;

  // attributed evictors according to ellis act withdrawal records. only
  // populated for evictions of type "Ellis Act Withdrawal"
  //
  // todo verify semantics. ad-hoc testing on april 2020 dataset shows a list
  // of multiple ellis evictors, which appear to be derived from interpreting a
  // string as a comma-separated list. As of 2020/09/26, the relationship
  // between this string and the ebook is not well documented.
  string ellis_evictor = 4;

  // a property of the EVICTED_BY relation connecting an SOS_Corp node with
  // this eviction's RB_Eviction node.
  //
  // todo: document what this field means.
  bool multiple_sales_matches = 5;

  ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
  // fields describing the parcel where this eviction took place:
  ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

  // block_lot of the parcel where this eviction tool place. uniquely specifies
  // a parcel in sf assessor records. unique key for A_Parcel nodes in the
  // database.
  string block_lot = 6;

  // num. units at the parcel where this eviction took place (via assessor
  // records).
  double units = 7;

  // latitude (in degrees) of a point within the boundaries of the parcel where
  // this eviction took place.
  double lat = 8;

  // longitude (in degrees) of a point within the boundaries of the parcel where
  // this eviction took place.
  double long = 9;

  // street address of the parcel where this eviction took place (via assessor
  // records). see 'addr' field of DirectlyOwnedParcelInfo.
  string addr = 10;

  // name of the neighorhood that encompasses the parcel where this eviction
  // took place (via assessor records). see 'neighborhood' field of
  // DirectlyOwnedParcelInfo.
  string neighborhood = 11; 

  // a property of the EVICTION_AT relation connecting this eviction to a
  // parcel record in the ebook dataset.  todo: document what this field means.
  bool multiple_addr_matches = 12;


  ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
  // fields describing attributed evictors and business networks:
  ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

  // only set when this eviction is part of a location-based query (ex:
  // neighborhood lookup). when set, contains the name of an attributed
  // evictor, or "Unknown" if there are no attributed evictors.
  //
  // when this message is part of a business-info query result, name is unset.
  string name = 13;

  // contains id's used to refer to a business holding network.
  //  
  // only set when eviction message is part of a location-based query (ex:
  // lookup by neighborhood). unset when this message appears in a
  // business-info query result.
  BusinessNetworkIdentifier linked_be = 14;
}

server/schemas/legacy/proto/query/graph_util.proto

// query/graph_util.proto
//
// contains helper messages for describing neo4j graphs.
syntax = "proto3";

package query;

// this schema, based on the neo4j-driver api, is good for representing
// arbitrary graphs, so it would be useful to adapt the graph proto layer to
// use it as well.
//
// IMPORTANT: see comments on 'properties' below; there are some gotchas.

////////////////////////////////////
// actual definitions begin here:
////////////////////////////////////

// representation of a node in the graph, including internal details
// particular to the graph's instantiation.
//
// based on the json schema of neo4j data driver's query results.
message GraphNode {
  // internal graph db id for this node.
  int64 identity = 1;

  // the node types that this node has. in our graph, nodes always have a
  // single type, as of 2021/03/12, but this may change in the future.
  repeated string labels = 2;

  // a json string representing a map of this node's properties, where the keys
  // are the property names and the values are strings, numbers, or objects.
  //
  // NOTE: this field does not appear in the response objects returned by
  // neo4j-driver.
  //
  // in the neo4j driver's response, 'properties' is a plain object. this is
  // convenient for the programming api, but it means that the driver's query
  // response can never be fully-type-safely specified as proto.
  //
  // this is because the schema of 'properties' is unpredictable (determined by
  // the contents of the db). you could choose to represent it as a map of
  // strings/bytes/Any/etc., but the native json representation of the proto
  // wouldn't match the actual neo4j driver's response.
  //
  // since we can't acheive perfect compatibility, the simplest strategy is to
  // encode the 'properties' object as json. callers should 'JSON.parse' the
  // value of 'properties_json' into 'properties' to achieve compatibility with
  // the neo4j driver api.
  // 
  // similarly, callers should 'JSON.stringify' the 'properties' value of a
  // neo4j driver response into 'properties_json' to allow encoding as proto.
  string properties_json = 3;

  // see above. the neo4j-driver object equivalent uses the name 'properties';
  // to make conversion code clearer, don't reuse that name.
  bytes properties = 4 [deprecated = true];
}

// representation of a relation (edge) in the graph, including internal details
// particular to the graph's instantiation. based on the js obj schema of
// neo4j-driver's query results.
//
// NOTE: a GraphRelation as described here contains the complete set of info
// for both nodes that it connects! that means that storing a graph as a list
// of these GraphRelation objects is inefficient, because the same node may be
// described many times (once for each connecting edge).
message GraphRelation {
  // origin node of the relation.
  GraphNode start = 1;

  // destination node of the relation. NOTE: as of 2021/03/12, edges are
  // treated as though they bidirectional in ebook graph analysis.
  GraphNode end = 2;

  // the relation/edge's type in the graph ("ENTITY_OWNED_BY", etc.).
  string type = 3;
}

server/schemas/legacy/proto/query/network.proto

// query/network.proto
//
// type definitions for network analysis of businesses, property-holders, and
// evictors in ebook serving query abstraction layer.
syntax = "proto3";

package query;

// id and location characteristics of a real-estate business network.
message NetworkLocationInfo {
  // an address in the ebook datastore where the central owning entity of a
  // real-estate business network is believed to be located.
  string addr_readable = 1;

  // network id of the real-estate business network believed to be
  // headquartered at addr_readable.
  int64 network_id = 2;
}

// id's used to refer to a real-estate holding network, as modeled by
// analysis of the calif. sec. of state business registry.
//
// see the developer guide for a detailed description of the evictorbook's
// network connection methodology in the section "Network Connection Method -
// Detailed > During DB Creation".
//
// c_id assignment is described in step 'I' of that section and network_id
// assignment is described in step 'III'.
//
// TODO: This message name is inaccurate; it really represents a Business, not
// a Network. Need to rename.
message BusinessNetworkIdentifier {
  // type of business record in ebook datastore ("SOS_LP", "SOS_Corp") from
  // which this business information was extracted.
  string __typename = 1;

  // business network id of this business in ebook datastore, as inferred
  // by graph analysis. see graph schema documentation for details.
  int64 network_id = 2;

  // connected component id of this business in ebook datastore, as
  // inferred by graph analysis. all businesses with the same c_id must
  // also have the same network_id, though two businesses with the same
  // network_id may have different c_id's. see graph documentation and
  // developer guide for details.
  int64 c_id = 3;

  // normalized name of the business in the ebook datastore (node type:
  // "SOS_LP" or "SOS_Corp") from which this network information was extracted.
  string name_norm = 4;
}

server/schemas/legacy/proto/query/parcel.proto

// query/parcel.proto
//
// describes the CYPHER queries invoked at serving-time to retrieve
// parcel-related information from the ebook datastore.
syntax = "proto3";

import "network.proto";

package query;

/////////////////////////////
//  Parcel detail messages: 
/////////////////////////////

// detailed info about a real-estate parcel from the sf assessor's office.
//
// corresponds to the object returned by parcel/details.js.
// originally derived from parcel_details subquery in parcel.js (deprecated).
message SFAssessorParcelDetails {
  // year in which the buildings on this real-estate parcel were first constructed.
  // TODO: describe behavior for multi-building parcels.
  int32 yr_built = 1;

  // string containing parcel's street address, including street number, street
  // name and suffix, and unit number. parcel is assumed to be within sf
  // city/county limits.
  //
  // notes from schema definition sheet:
  // full address in the format of "ST_START_NO-ST_END_NO ST_NAME ST_TYPE (Unit
  // UNIT)" (w/o end no if no address range, w/o parentheses if no unit)
  string addr = 2;

  // 'block_lot' identifier. unique key for a parcel in sf assessor records,
  // and uniqye key for A_Parcel nodes in the database.
  string block_lot = 3;

  // latitude in degrees of a point within this parcel's boundaries.
  //
  // TODO: specify bounds.
  double lat = 4;

  // longitude in degrees of a point within this parcel's boundaries.
  //
  // TODO: specify bounds.
  double long = 5;

  // name of the neighborhood this parcel occupies. as of 2020/09/26, it's
  // assumed that all parcels are within sf city and county, so these are san
  // francisco neighborhoods.
  //
  // neighborhoods assigned using sf polygons.
  //
  // names and polygon boundaries:
  // https://data.sfgov.org/Geographic-Locations-and-Boundaries/SF-Find-Neighborhoods/pty2-tcw4
  string neighborhood = 6;

  // rough assessment of this parcel's rent-control status.
  //
  // 0 (default) if data unavailable to determine rent controlled status, 
  // 1 if likely rent controlled,
  // 2 if doubtful that this is rent controlled
  int32 rent_controlled = 7;

  // property class code, via sf assessor's office.
  // definitons:
  // https://data.sfgov.org/Housing-and-Buildings/Reference-Assessor-Recorder-Property-Class-Codes/pa56-ek2h/data
  string prop_class_code = 8;

  // i.d. for the zoning district this parcel occupies.
  // sf zoning district definitions:
  // https://sfplanninggis.org/pim/map.html?layers=Zoning%20Districts
  string zone = 9;

  // how tall is the building on this parcel, in stories.
  // TODO: behavior for multi-building parcels?
  int32 stories = 10;

  // number of physical units within this logical real-estate parcel.
  int32 units = 11;

  // number of total rooms within buildings on this parcel (for multi-unit
  // parcels, this is the sum of rooms among all units.)
  int32 rooms = 12;

  // number of total bedrooms on this parcel (for multi-unit parcels, this is
  // the sum of bedrooms among all units.)
  int32 beds = 13;

  // assessor valuation of the 'land' base value, i.e. the parcel's theoretical
  // value if it had no buildings on it.
  int32 assess_land_val = 14;

  // assessor valuation of the 'improvement' done to the land via development,
  // as of most recent assessment. units in u.s. dollars.
  int32 assess_imp_val = 15;

  // date when the parcel's value was last assessed. format: CCYYMMDD
  string assess_val_date = 16;

  // date on which this parcel's address was last updated, via assessor
  // records. format: CCYYMMDD
  string update_date = 17;

  // units in u.s. dollars.  TODO: document when and how this gets populated.
  int32 curr_sales_price = 18;
